prompt: How to do dips on parallel bars? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Get into position with a bench behind you. You can use any sturdy bench or chair, such as a workout bench or even a park bench. You can even do these off the edge of your bed. [1] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview Sit on the edge of the bench and put a hand down on either side of your legs. Your hands should be about shoulder-width apart. Straighten out your arms. Place your feet flat on the ground with your knees at a 90-degree angle. Raising your feet off of the ground will make the exercise more challenging. [3] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview 2. Tighten your core and lower your body off the bench. Squeeze your core muscles to tighten them. Move yourself off the front edge of the bench and use your arms to lower yourself down toward the floor. Don't go all the way down. Dip down enough that your elbows end up at a 90-degree angle. 3. Keep your head and upper body straight. As you dip, make sure your body stays upright. Look straight ahead to remind yourself not to dip your head while you're performing a dip. Also, keep your elbows close to your body. 4. Hold the dipped position for 1-2 seconds before pushing back up. When you reach the bottom of the dip, stay there for a couple of seconds. That will force your arm muscles to work harder while you hold yourself in place. Once you've held the position, move your body back up, keeping your core tight as you do. At the top, lock your elbows momentarily. 5. Move yourself up and down without returning to the bench. Keep going for the whole set, doing 8 to 10 reps at a time. When you move your body down, try to do it in slow motion. Moving more slowly works your muscles harder. Try 2-3 sets at a time. For a variation, straighten your legs out in front of you instead of bending at the knees.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** (to go with the visual above):

### Parallel Bar Dips — Step-by-step

1. **Setup**

   * Grip bars just outside shoulder width. Wrists neutral, thumbs around bars.
   * Press down to lift your body; legs slightly bent and crossed behind you.
   * Set your shoulders: **down and back** (depress & lightly retract). Brace your core.

2. **Descent**

   * Inhale. Lean your torso slightly forward.
   * Bend elbows, letting them travel **back at ~30–45°**, not flared wide.
   * Keep forearms close to vertical; don’t shrug.

3. **Bottom position**

   * Stop when **upper arms are about parallel** to the floor (or a touch below) **without shoulder pain**.
   * Chest open, neck neutral, scapulae still depressed.

4. **Drive up**

   * Exhale and **push the bars straight down**.
   * Think “chest up, shoulders down.”
   * Elbows extend while staying stacked over wrists.

5. **Lockout**

   * Finish tall with elbows straight (not hyperextended).
   * Reset shoulder position before the next rep. Breathe, then repeat.

---

### Tips & Cues

* “**Push the bars to the floor**,” “**shoulders down**,” “**elbows back, not out**.”
* Tempo for control: **2–3s down, 1s up**, pause briefly at the top.
* Start with **3–4 sets of 5–8 reps**; leave 1–2 reps in reserve.

### Common Mistakes

* Elbows flaring wide.
* Shoulders shrugging toward ears.
* Half-depth reps or bouncing at the bottom.
* Swinging/kipping or craning the neck forward.

### Progressions & Regressions

* **Easier:** band-assisted dips, feet on a box, or eccentric-only (slow lower, step up).
* **Harder:** pause at the bottom for 1–2s, add weight with a dip belt, or do ring dips (advanced).

> If you feel shoulder discomfort, reduce depth, slow the tempo, or switch to assisted versions until you build strength and control.

Gemini_text:
Here's how to do dips on parallel bars, with visual steps and text explanations:

**Step 1: Starting Position**
Grip the parallel bars with your palms facing inward (neutral grip). Push yourself up so your arms are fully extended and your body is suspended above the bars. Keep your core engaged and your legs straight, or slightly bent with ankles crossed, directly below you.


**Step 2: Lowering Phase**
Slowly lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping them tucked close to your body. Lean slightly forward to engage your chest muscles more effectively. Continue lowering until your shoulders are below your elbows, or until you feel a good stretch in your chest and shoulders.

prompt: How to Do a Straddle Press Handstand? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Start in a seated straddle position. Sit down on your butt with your legs extended out to either side of your body at roughly a 45-degree angle. Engage your glutes to hold your legs straight and firm and rotate your knees in slightly, which will help you engage your core in turn. When you’re reading to begin the press, place your hands shoulder-width apart on the floor in front of you. There’s no single best width where the straddle is concerned—a wider straddle will provide better leg clearance but requires more strength, whereas a narrower straddle will offer greater stability but will make it harder to get your legs out of the way. Do what’s most comfortable for you. If you prefer, you can also start in a standing position, with your feet a little wider than hip-width apart and your hands on the floor directly beneath your shoulders. This position will give you a little more leverage, which can be helpful if you don’t have the strength required to press all the way up from the floor. 2. Lean forward over your hands slowly. As your torso begins to tilt, transfer your weight from your lower body to your hands. Press your palms firmly into the floor and maintaining a small amount of bend in your elbows. Spread your fingers out on the floor as much as you can to create a wider base and lend added stability to your handstand. 3. Engage your core as you continue leaning to begin lifting your legs. Tense the muscles of your midsection tight. You should be able to feel an equal amount of tension in your upper and lower abs, hips, and pelvis. Imagine that your entire upper body from the crown of your head to your tailbone is one straight line. Focus on keeping your torso as rigid as possible during the first part of the press. If you’re too loose, your own weight will be working against you, decreasing your leverage and pulling you off balance. Make sure your head stays well in front of your hands to serve as a counter-lever to your lower body. If you can look down between your hands, you’re not leaning out far enough. 4. Keep your shoulders ahead of your hips until your feet clear the floor. Continue shifting more and more of your weight forward. Finding a good point of balance between your head and your hips is crucial at this stage, as most of your lower body will still be behind you. When only your toes remain on the floor, you’re ready to begin pulling upward into the handstand. Extend your shoulders completely by pushing your straight arms down away from your head. This will distribute more of your weight among your trapezius, scapula, and core muscles, which are much stronger than the muscles of the arms themselves. Avoid letting your knees bend, if you can help it. Just like a loose torso, relaxed legs can create an imbalance. 5. Pick your legs up off of the floor and raise them out to the sides. Without breaking your forward lean, tighten your glutes, hamstrings, and core to prepare to lift your legs. In one controlled movement, sweep them back behind you and upwards. As they leave the floor, your upper and lower body will briefly be in the same configuration they were in in your starting position, only inverted. Don’t rush the leg lift. Doing so could cause you to wobble or overshoot your mark and fall forward. The key to a solid straddle press is to perform each movement in a slow, controlled manner. Keep your awareness on your hands, arms, and shoulders as your legs come up. Otherwise, you may lose tightness and topple over prematurely. 6. Bring your legs together over your head to complete the handstand. As you straighten your legs, your hips will naturally move into alignment with your shoulders. At this point, you can stop leaning forward and concentrate on fine-tuning your balance through your hands. Maintain this “stacked” position to hold the handstand for as long as you can. Dialing in your handstand may feel harder than normal, since you’ll already be fatigued. Do your best to hold the position with good form for 5-10 seconds, then gradually increase your time to build up your endurance. If you need some assistance, practice pressing up against a wall, or have a friend spot you by holding your hips once you get inverted. The added support will help you learn how to transition between each part of the movement without having to worry about maintaining your balance. 7. Lower yourself back down to the floor by reversing the sequence. With your core nice and tight, slowly separate your legs and begin hinging at the waist to bring them down in front of your body. Lean forward and keep your head in front of your hands like you did on the way up to maintain your balance. Place your feet on the floor and stand up if you started in a standing position. If you pressed up from seated position, bend your arms to bring yourself back down to a seated straddle. As your straddle press handstands improve, you can start performing multiple “reps,” going from straddle to handstand and back again without ever setting your full weight back down. 8. Practice your straddle press handstand frequently. The straddle press handstand is an advanced-level skill that requires a tremendous amount of strength, balance, flexibility and coordination. Make it a point to develop each part of the movement individually until it becomes easy to transition to the next stage. Not only will a slow progression help you prioritize proper form from beginning to end, it will also minimize your risk of injury. Try to set aside 15-30 minutes per day to practice. The more you train, the quicker you’ll get the hang of it. Stop practicing when you feel your form start to slip. You don’t want to get in the habit of performing the movement with poor technique.

GPT_text:
Here are the text steps to pair with the visual:
	1.	Setup

	•	Warm up wrists, hamstrings, and shoulders.
	•	Stand in a wide straddle. Place palms shoulder-width on the floor slightly in front of your toes.
	•	Lock elbows. “Push tall” (shoulders protracted & elevated). Light hollow body.

	2.	Compress

	•	Hinge at the hips and fold forward.
	•	Exhale and pull thighs toward ribs; keep knees straight.
	•	Rise onto tiptoes to shift weight into your hands.

	3.	Lean

	•	Without bending the elbows, lean shoulders slightly past wrists.
	•	Eyes between thumbs, neck neutral. Keep pushing the floor.

	4.	Float (toes peel off)

	•	Let the toes lift softly from the floor—no kicking.
	•	Keep legs wide and low while maintaining compression.

	5.	Stack

	•	Continue the tiny forward lean until hips are directly over your hands.
	•	Maintain posterior pelvic tilt (no early back arch).

	6.	Lift

	•	With hips stacked, use core compression to arc straight legs up in a wide straddle.
	•	Think “up and around,” not “back and kick.”

	7.	Balance

	•	Hold a straddle handstand: elbows locked, shoulders elevated, ribs tucked, glutes lightly on.
	•	Breathe slow and keep fingers active for balance.

	8.	Finish (optional)

	•	Smoothly bring legs together to full handstand, then straddle back down with control to exit.

Quick tips
	•	Cues: “Lock elbows,” “Push tall,” “Exhale to compress,” “Hips over hands first.”
	•	Drills: box/bench straddle press, press negatives, seated straddle/pike lifts, scapular push-ups, wall nose-to-wall holds.
	•	Common mistakes: bending arms, sinking shoulders, kicking up, looking forward, closing legs before hips are stacked.
	•	Safety: clear space, practice near a wall or with a spotter; stop for sharp wrist/shoulder pain.

Gemini_text:
Here's a breakdown of how to achieve a straddle press handstand, with visual aids:

**Step 1: Warm-up and Wrist Preparation**

Before attempting any handstand, it's crucial to thoroughly warm up your wrists, shoulders, and core. Perform wrist circles, push-up pluses, and some light stretching.

**Step 2: Pike Compression Practice**

Pike compression is key. Sit on the floor with straight legs, and try to bring your chest as close to your thighs as possible. This builds the necessary core strength and flexibility. **Step 3: Elevated Pike Press (or Pike Handstand Prep)**

Place your hands on the floor and your feet on an elevated surface (like a yoga block or low step) in a pike position. Practice lifting one leg at a time, focusing on keeping your hips stacked over your shoulders. This helps you get used to the inverted position and balance.

**Step 4: Straddle Leg Lifts (on the floor)**

From a seated straddle position, place your hands on the floor in front of you. Lean forward and try to lift your hips off the ground, engaging your core and pressing through your hands. This simulates the initial lift of the straddle press.

**Step 5: Full Straddle Press Handstand**

Start in a deep straddle pike. Place your hands shoulder-width apart, fingers spread. Shift your weight forward, lifting your hips and engaging your core. As your hips rise, slowly press up into a handstand, keeping your legs straddled until you find your balance, then bring them together.

prompt: How to Do a Tricep Workout? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Perform an overhead triceps extension for a basic way to flex. Pick up a pair of dumbbells that aren’t too heavy for you, then stand up straight. Lift your arms straight up over your head. Then, bend your elbows to lower the dumbbells behind your head. Do 3 sets of up to 12 repetitions for a decent challenge. This exercise can also be done sitting down. It’s a little easier when you’re sitting on a chair or bench since you don’t have to try as hard to stay balanced. 2. Practice a dumbbell jab if you wish to increase your endurance. Pick up a couple of light dumbbells and stand up straight with your legs shoulder-width apart. Hold the dumbbells up close to your body with your elbows bent and your palms facing one another. Then, push one of the dumbbells forward and across your body like you’re boxing. Repeat the motion with your other hand, doing up to 2 sets of 12 repetitions with each arm. Keep the dumbbells level with your shoulders as you move them. Tense your core muscles to maintain your form. In addition to testing your endurance, jabs work your chest, abs, and other muscles. Work up a sweat as part of your routine or to warm up for tougher exercises! 3. Do triceps kickbacks with a bench for stable strengthening. Stand next to a weight bench, then plant one knee and hand on it. While holding a dumbbell at your side, raise your free arm up until it’s about level with your back. Do the kickback by moving the dumbbell back toward your feet until your arm straightens out and is parallel to the floor. Do about 3 sets of 12 repetitions on each side to complete the exercise. This exercise is all about moving slowly, so take your time with it. Stop if your elbow feels stiff and switch to a lighter weight. You could do this exercise while standing. Bend forward to level out your back like you would while leaning on a bench. 4. Try lying dumbbell extensions for an easy way to isolate triceps. Grab a pair of dumbbells, then lie down on a bench. Raise your arms straight up to the ceiling, then bring the dumbbells back down to the top of your head. Hold your forearms still while you do this so your triceps do the work. Go through 3 sets of 10 to 12 repetitions each to complete the exercise. There are a couple of different ways to hold the dumbbells, so choose whichever one feels more comfortable. You could position them horizontally with your palms facing up or vertically with your hands wrapped around them. 5. Do a dumbbell bench press if you’re looking to strengthen your arms. Lie down on a bench, tucking your arms close to your chest. Keep your elbows bent, then push the dumbbells up above your chest. Bring the dumbbells back down and repeat the motion for 3 sets of 10 to 12 repetitions each. This exercise hits your triceps hard but it also engages your shoulders and chest. It’s a simplified version of the bench press done with a barbell. Reader Poll: We asked 649 wikiHow readers what type of exercise they enjoy most for arm workouts, and 72% of them said weightlifting. [Take Poll] 6. Do cross-body unilateral exercises to flex the sides of your triceps. Sit down on a bench, facing the side. Plant your hand near the edge of the bench and lean toward it so your body is at about a 75-degree angle. Using your opposite hand, raise a dumbbell straight up above your head. Bring the dumbbell down behind your head while keeping your forearm still. Complete 3 sets of up to 12 repetitions with each arm. Use this exercise to stretch out each triceps individually. The motion is a lot different than most other exercises, so it’s a good way to add variety to your routine. Another option is to lay down on the bench and bring the dumbbell down toward your forehead. Work on your triceps one at a time for greater strength and stability.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** to match the 4 visual steps:

1. Close-Grip Push-Up

* Start in a straight-line plank, hands under shoulders and slightly closer than shoulder-width.
* Keep elbows tucked ~45° to your sides as you lower your chest toward the floor; press back to plank.
* Reps: 8–15. Too hard? Drop to knees or elevate hands on a bench.
* Cues: Squeeze glutes, brace core, keep neck neutral.

2. Bench/Chair Dips

* Sit on a sturdy bench/chair, hands on the edge beside hips, fingers forward; scoot hips off the edge. Knees bent ~90°.
* Lower by bending elbows straight back until about 90°, then press up without shrugging.
* Reps: 8–15. Make it harder by straightening legs.
* Cues: Chest tall, shoulders down and back; don’t sink shoulders or flare elbows wide.

3. Overhead Dumbbell Extension

* Stand or sit tall, hold one dumbbell with both hands above head; upper arms vertical, ribs down.
* Bend elbows to lower the weight behind your head, then extend to straight, keeping elbows pointing forward.
* Reps: 10–15.
* Cues: Brace your core; move only at the elbows.

4. Dumbbell Kickback

* Hinge at the hips with a flat back; hold dumbbells at sides, elbows bent ~90°, upper arms parallel to torso.
* Extend forearms straight back and squeeze triceps; return slowly.
* Reps: 10–15.
* Cues: Keep upper arms glued to your sides; avoid swinging.

Quick workout format

* Do Steps 1–4 as a circuit, **2–4 rounds**. Rest **60–90 sec** between rounds.
* Choose loads that leave **1–2 reps in reserve** each set.
* Finish with a gentle triceps/shoulder stretch. Stop if you feel sharp pain.

If you want swaps (resistance bands, cables) or a version for home/no weights, I can tailor it!

Gemini_text:
Here's a tricep workout routine with visual steps to guide you:

### Tricep Workout Routine

**1. Close-Grip Bench Press**
   * **Setup:** Lie on a flat bench, grasping the barbell with an overhand grip, hands about shoulder-width apart or slightly closer. Your elbows should be tucked in close to your body.
   * **Execution:** Lower the barbell slowly towards your lower chest, keeping your elbows close. Push the barbell back up to the starting position, focusing on squeezing your triceps at the top.
   * **Sets & Reps:** 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions.
   

**2. Overhead Dumbbell Tricep Extension**
   * **Setup:** Sit on a bench or stand, holding one dumbbell with both hands. Extend the dumbbell directly overhead, with your arms fully stretched.
   * **Execution:** Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. Keep your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position, feeling the stretch in your triceps.
   * **Sets & Reps:** 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.

prompt: How to do a bench press? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Begin by lying flat on the bench, with your body in a natural and relaxed position. Make sure that you are not holding your shoulders in an awkward position. Be sure to have a natural spinal curve. You do not want to have your lower back flat on the bench, but you do not want to force it to curve too much either. Instead, opt for a comfortable and natural position. You should have your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart, and your shoulders touching the bench. Do not lift on a "cushiony bench" if you are a heavy lifter. When the bar and plates weigh more than 200 pounds plus the weight of your upper body, your shoulders will disappear into the bench and cause neck strain. Choose a proper bench that fits your shoulder width. A narrow bench is unstable and a wide bench prevents the upper arm from bending back. 2. Put your arms straight out to either side of you, and then bend your elbows, bringing your hands up to touch the bar. This is where you should position your hands. They should be about shoulder-width apart. Use the smooth rings in the bar as a reference for even hand placement. Where you position your hands will affect which muscle group you work most. Widen your grip slightly to increase the amount of pectoral muscles involved in this exercise, and bring your grip in slightly to increase your triceps involvement. For a standard bench press, opt for the normal grip. 3. Begin with just the bar weight to warm up before heavy lifting. Lift the bar off the rack and position it directly above the middle of your chest. Inhale as you lower it down, gently touching your chest — the middle of the sternum — with the bar. Do not bounce the bar off your chest, as this can cause serious injury and promotes bad form . Begin to exhale as you push the bar up and away from your body. Extend your arms to just under full extension. Repeat this for eight repetitions as your first set. Lift with a bar that has a little flex but is not "whippy". A stiff bar can be uncomfortable to lift with. All bars are made of metal and relatively stiff, but a bar with some flex feels better on the joints. The salesperson at the store will give you the right bar for your bodyweight, based on the formula for bodyweight and bench press. Generally, a beginning or intermediate lifter is not going to lift over his bodyweight plus 50%. Examine your goals when choosing a bar. For setting a personal record or a state record and above, use a bar with a standard diameter of 1 1 ⁄ 16 inches (2.7 cm). If not concerned with records, a thicker bar does not dig into the palms and is more comfortable. A thicker bar increases the distance of the lift and decreases the amount that can be lifted. A 1/8 (or 1/16) inch increase in bar diameter has a noticeable difference in feel and stability. 4. Rack the bar and add weight. Always use weight clips to prevent the weights from sliding off the bar in the event that you lift unevenly, do not lift without them. The bar by itself weighs 45 pounds. You will want to increase by five to ten pounds at a time until you find a comfortable weight. Practice extra caution if tall. Tall lifters with wide grips should use care not to crush their hands when racking the bar. Weight benches were made for someone tall (6 feet tall and not for a lifter 6 feet 8 inches tall). Tall lifters should not use an extra wide grip. An extra wide grip strains the wrist with excessive radial flexion. Close and wide grips can make the wrist more prone to injury. Avoid using the thumbless grip. If the bar slips off your hands, it would be disastrous. When being spotted by spotters and by a spotting device the thumbless grip is not as dangerous, but the spotting device has to be very, very solid. The thumbless grips is easier on the wrist and conducts power to the bar more directly (you can lift more). Use chalk with both grips. There are lifters who will use the thumbless grips despite the possible danger. 5. Be sure to have a spotter to help you whenever you lift a heavy weight. You never want to drop the bar on yourself. You also want to be able to max out and be able to recover when you no longer can lift the bar. A spotter will be able to help you recover from your final press. 6. Lift the bar up, slowly bring it down to just above your sternum, and explode upward for one rep. Pay attention to your form as you add more weight. It's easier to bend your wrists, bounce the weight off your chest, and exhibit other "no-nos" when trying to lift big. You'll gain more muscle and strength lifting the right form and lower weight than you will lifting with higher weight and the wrong form. Lifters generally do between 8 and 12 reps (also called "repetitions") and 3 to six sets (one set is the maximum numbers of reps you give yourself). 7. Drink plenty of water and take at least two minute breaks between each set. Water will help you stay hydrated and allow your muscles to function at high capacity, giving you an overall better workout. 8. Rest according to how you feel between sets. Some guides say the ideal rest time between sets is 90 to 120 seconds. While this is perhaps a good general guide for increasing muscle mass, it may not be ideal for you as an individual. You probably don't want to overshoot the 2-3 minute range, but you don't want to rush yourself into lifting thin. If your ultimate goal is gaining muscle and mass, you're going to want to shock your body. How you do this is up to you. It can mean cutting down on rest time, increasing poundage on lifts, supersetting, etc. As long as you manage to keep pushing your body physically, you will notice a difference.

GPT_text:
Here are the steps in text (image is above):

# How to perform a forearm plank (step-by-step)

1. Set up

* Kneel on a mat. Place **forearms on the floor**, elbows directly under shoulders. Hands parallel (either palms flat or lightly make fists).

2. Brace before you lift

* Take a small inhale. On the exhale, **brace your core** like you’re about to be lightly poked in the stomach.
* Squeeze glutes and lightly **tuck the pelvis** (posterior tilt) to keep the low back neutral.
* Press the floor away so your shoulder blades spread slightly (no shoulder shrug).

3. Step back to plank

* Extend one leg back, then the other so you’re on your toes.
* Feet hip-width apart (wider is easier for balance).

4. Find your straight line

* Ears-to-ankles in one line: **neck long, gaze down**, ribs stacked over pelvis, hips neither sagging nor piked.
* Keep quads tight and heels pushing back.

5. Breathe & hold

* Breathe quietly—**3–4 second inhale, 3–5 second exhale**.
* Hold for **10–30 seconds** with perfect form. Rest, then do 2–4 sets. (Advance toward 30–60 seconds if pain-free and form is solid.)

6. Finish

* Gently **lower your knees** to the mat, then sit back and relax the shoulders.

### Quick checkpoints

* Elbows under shoulders
* Ribs down, pelvis slightly tucked
* Hips level with shoulders
* Head in line with spine
* Steady breathing

### Common mistakes (avoid)

* Sagging or hiking the hips
* Letting the low back arch or the head drop
* Shrugging into the neck or collapsing through the shoulders
* Holding your breath

### Easier options

* **Knee plank** (knees on the mat, same alignment)
* **Hands elevated** on a bench or countertop (high plank)

### Harder options (when ready)

* **High plank** on hands
* **Side plank** (stack feet, elbow under shoulder)
* **Single-leg or shoulder tap** holds while keeping hips still

If anything hurts—especially your lower back—stop, reset your alignment, or choose an easier option.

Gemini_text:
The bench press is a popular exercise for building upper body strength. Here's how to do it with visual steps:

1.  **Set up the Bench and Bar:** Lie on a flat bench with your feet flat on the floor. Your eyes should be directly under the barbell. Grip the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, palms facing your feet. Ensure the bar is racked securely.
 
2.  **Unrack the Bar:** Take a deep breath, brace your core, and unrack the bar from the supports. Hold it directly above your chest with your arms fully extended.
 
3.  **Lower the Bar:** Slowly lower the bar towards your mid-chest, keeping your elbows tucked in slightly (about a 45-degree angle to your body). Control the movement until the bar lightly touches your chest or is just above it.
 
4.  **Press the Bar Up:** Exhale and powerfully press the bar back up to the starting position, extending your arms fully. Focus on using your chest muscles.

prompt: How To Do A Lat Pulldown? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Grasp the bar with a wide, overhand, knuckles-up grip. Other positions and grips are possible but start with this standard position. 2. Pull the lat pulldown bar until it's approximately level with the chin. Exhale on the downward motion. While shifting slightly backward is OK, aim to keep your upper torso stationary. Keep your feet flat on the floor and engage your abs as you pull. The bottom of the motion should be where your elbows can't move downward anymore without moving backward. Be sure to stop at that point and do not go lower. 3. Squeeze the shoulder blades together while maintaining square shoulders. 4. From the bottom position with the bar close to your chin, slowly return the lat pulldown bar to the starting position while controlling its gradual ascent. Don't let it crash into the weight plates.

GPT_text:
Here you go—image first, then the text steps (kept separate as requested).

# Visual Steps (use this image)

I created a clear, step-by-step infographic showing setup, movement, and common mistakes for the lat pulldown.

# Text Steps

1. Set the machine

* Adjust the thigh pad so your thighs are snugly pinned; feet flat.
* Choose a weight you can control for 8–12 reps without jerking.

2. Grip the bar

* Overhand (pronated) grip just outside shoulder width.
* Wrists straight; thumbs around the bar.

3. Position your body

* Sit tall, ribcage down, slight lean back (~10–20°).
* Neutral spine, core lightly braced, eyes forward.

4. Pack the shoulders (start the rep)

* Before pulling, “set” your shoulder blades: down and slightly back (think: put them in your back pockets).
* Elbows point down, not back.

5. Pull to the upper chest

* Drive elbows toward the floor, bar traveling in front of your face.
* Touch (or nearly touch) the top of your chest, just below the collarbones.
* Keep forearms vertical; avoid shrugging.

6. Squeeze & pause

* Brief 1-second pause; feel lats contracting while shoulders stay down.

7. Controlled return

* Let the bar rise over 2–3 seconds, arms straightening without losing shoulder control.
* Keep tension; don’t let the weight stack slam.

8. Breathe

* Inhale at the top (stretch), exhale as you pull down; small breath hold through the hardest part is okay if you’re experienced and blood pressure is normal.

9. Tempo & range

* Full comfortable stretch at the top without shoulder roll-forward; smooth, no swinging.
* Typical tempo: 2–3s down, 1s pause, 2–3s up.

10. Sets & reps

* Hypertrophy: 3–4 sets × 8–12 reps.
* Strength: 4–5 sets × 5–8 reps (slightly heavier, perfect form).
* Beginners: start with 2–3 sets × 10–12 reps light.

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

* Pulling the bar **behind the neck** (unnecessary shoulder stress).
* Using momentum/leaning way back (turns it into a row).
* Gripping **too wide** (shortens range, stresses shoulders) or too narrow (turns into more biceps).
* Shrugging shoulders up toward ears.
* Breaking wrists (bent wrists reduce transfer of force).

## Variations

* Neutral-grip (V-bar) pulldown: easier on shoulders, great lat engagement.
* Underhand (supinated) pulldown: more biceps, slightly lower-lat bias.
* Single-arm cable pulldown: fixes imbalances, allows tailored line of pull.
* Pause or 1½-rep pulldowns: increase time under tension.

## Form Cues (quick reminders)

“Chest tall, ribs down • Elbows to pockets • Bar to upper chest • Control the return • Don’t shrug.”

If you want, I can also generate alternate visuals (e.g., neutral-grip version, single-arm version) to match your equipment.

Gemini_text:
The lat pulldown is a fantastic exercise for building a strong, wide back. Here's how to do it with proper form:

**Step 1: Setup**
Adjust the knee pad so your thighs are snug under it when seated. This will help keep you stable during the exercise. Reach up and grasp the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your arms should be fully extended.


**Step 2: Initiate the Pull**
Lean back slightly (about 15-30 degrees) and puff out your chest. Take a deep breath and, as you exhale, begin to pull the bar down towards your upper chest. Focus on driving your elbows down and back, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
**Step 3: The Contraction**
Continue to pull the bar down until it's just above your upper chest or clavicle. At this point, your lats should be fully contracted. Hold the contraction for a brief moment, really feeling the squeeze in your back muscles.


**Step 4: Controlled Release**
Slowly and with control, allow the bar to ascend back to the starting position. Resist the urge to let the weight snap back up quickly. Keep your core engaged and maintain tension in your lats throughout the upward movement.

prompt: How to Do a Front Flip? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Stand in an extended straight line. Stand straight up with your legs together and raise your hands straight above your head. Your body should form one straight line. Stretch your arms up as high as you can so that your hands and feet are as far apart as possible. 2. Lean into the roll. Keeping your knees as straight as possible, move your arms, head, and trunk down as one unit. You should not be bending down at the waist. Instead, try to keep your torso and legs in a line, which means your legs should go down as your torso lowers to the ground. Reach toward the ground as you lean into the roll. Your hands will connect with the floor as your body goes down as one unit in an almost straight line. 3. Push your hips forward when your hands touch the floor. Your hands should touch the floor with your fingers pointing ahead of you. Your upper body should be all lined up with your hips slightly elevated. Bring your hips forward with your legs following. Make sure to keep your legs straight. Don’t fling your legs over your body. Move your chin towards your chest to protect your neck. 4. Roll forward onto your back. Keep your legs straight as you flip over on your hands in a slow, controlled motion. Bend your arms slightly as you roll onto your back. As you roll onto your back, tuck your knees towards your chest. Grasp your shins or your knees as your roll forward. 5. Stand up. As you roll from your back to a vertical position, roll flat onto your feet. As soon as your feet are flat on the floor, lift your arms over your head as you stand up. 6. Try a dive roll after you’ve mastered the front roll. Doing a dive roll will help you transition to a front flip. It’s similar to a front roll, but you jump instead of slowly lowering yourself into a roll. Start by running forward and jump from the balls of your feet. Keep your knees as straight as possible. Just like with the front roll, keep your body as straight as possible. When you jump, jump forward as you reach your arms forward toward the floor. When your hands touch the floor, go into the normal front roll you’ve already mastered.

Gemini_text:
A front flip, also known as a front somersault, is an exciting acrobatic move that involves rotating your body 360 degrees forward in the air. While it looks impressive, it requires practice, proper technique, and a safe environment. Here's a breakdown of how to approach learning a front flip:

**Step 1: Build Foundational Skills and Warm-up**
Before attempting a front flip, ensure you have a good level of physical fitness, including core strength, leg power, and flexibility. Start with a thorough warm-up, including dynamic stretches and light cardio, to prepare your muscles and joints. Practice basic tumbling skills like forward rolls and handstands to get comfortable with inversions.

**Step 2: The Take-Off**
The take-off is crucial for generating height and forward momentum. Start with a few steps to build speed. As you approach your take-off point, your last two steps should be quick and powerful. Explode upwards, driving your knees towards your chest. Your arms should swing up vigorously to aid in the lift.
**Step 3: The Tuck**
Immediately after your take-off, bring your knees as close to your chest as possible and grab your shins or the back of your thighs. This tight tuck position reduces your body's moment of inertia, allowing you to rotate faster. Keep your head neutral or slightly tucked, looking towards your knees.
**Step 4: The Rotation**
As you tuck, your body will naturally begin to rotate forward. Focus on maintaining a tight tuck throughout the rotation. Keep your eyes open to spot your landing. The speed of your rotation will depend on the power of your take-off and the tightness of your tuck.
**Step 5: The Untuck and Landing**
Once you've completed about three-quarters of the rotation and can spot the ground, begin to untuck your body. Extend your legs downwards, preparing for landing. Absorb the impact by bending your knees and hips. Try to land with your feet shoulder-width apart, arms out for balance.

Gemini_text_result.explanation: The answer breaks down the process of performing a front flip into five distinct, numbered steps. The steps are presented in a logical, chronological order (Warm-up, Take-Off, Tuck, Rotation, Landing), making the process sequential and clear to follow.

prompt: How to do a lateral raise with dumbbells? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Choose your weights. Select a few different dumbbell sizes to experiment with lifting. Make sure you can lift the dumbbell comfortably and repeatedly. Your focus for lateral raises will be building muscle tone, not on lifting heavy weights. While dumbbells are most popularly used for this exercise, they are not a requirement for doing lateral raises. You can use a resistance band if you’d prefer not to use dumbbells. The main difference between using a resistance band versus free weights is that with a resistance band, you will use your feet to keep the band in place as you pull up on the ends of the band. Your form and technique should be the same as it is with free weights. Selecting the correct weight is important and key for lateral raises, but do not get caught up with finding the perfect weight. Using a lighter weight will cause tension and resistance with the more reps you do each set. 2. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your legs shoulder-width apart, hip-width apart or in a split-stance position to keep your body stable. 3. Straighten your back and keep your chest out and open. The arm can be straight (but not locked) during this exercise. If you are using dumbbells, you can also bend your elbow at a 90° angle (do not bend the elbow to 90° if you are using a resistance band). 4. Keep your chest up, with a slight bend in your elbows. Pull your shoulder blades down and back. You should feel a slight tension in your shoulders, which is completely normal. 5. Hold a dumbbell in both hands and at your sides. Turn the palms of your hands inward so that they are facing your body. Keep your thumbs wrapped around the dumbbell handles, or turned toward the ceiling if you want to work out different muscle groups. Get your torso ready for the raises by tightening your abs and core muscles. If you are using a resistance band, stand on the center of the band and take a handle or end of the band in each hand. There should be some tension in the band. 6. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides, just below shoulder-height. Slowly lift each dumbbell out to the sides, like wings, until your arms are almost parallel to the ground, almost at shoulder-height. Slowly exhale as you use the muscles in the top of your shoulder to lift the dumbbells. Keep your head straight and aligned with your spine. It the lats are engaged, and the shoulder blades are retracted (as they are supposed to be), it is impossible to lift the arms above shoulder height. If the arms go above shoulder height, the lats are not engaged. If you are doing the exercise correctly, your arms will not go higher than the shoulders. If you are using a resistance band, lift the ends of the band as you raise your arms to shoulder-height or just slightly below. Hold the raise for two to three seconds with a slight bend in your elbow. Allow yourself to build a little tension in your shoulder, making the workout more effective. Keep your core engaged and stabilized. Do not flex your wrists or position your arm so that your wrists are higher than your elbows (they should be roughly at the same height or in line). If your wrists are held too high you will shift the work away from your shoulders. To prevent this, imagine the dumbbell is actually a bottle of water and you are tilting it forward to pour out the water. Reader Poll: We asked 310 wikiHow readers how they liked to refuel after a workout, and 52% of them said protein shake. [Take Poll] 7. Lower your arms slowly back to the start position. Take two to three seconds to slowly lower the dumbbells back down to your start position, steadily inhaling as you go. Your movement should be slow and controlled. If you are using a resistance band, slowly lower your hands back to the starting position. Do not allow the tension in the band to pull your arm back for you — this should be a controlled movement.

GPT_text:
# Text steps: Dumbbell Lateral Raise

1. **Set up**

* Stand hip-width apart, light dumbbells at your sides.
* Palms face your thighs, wrists straight, **elbows slightly bent**.
* Brace your core, keep a **neutral spine**, and set your shoulder blades **down and back** (no shrugging).

2. **Initiate the lift**

* Begin the motion from your **delts**, not your hands.
* **Lead with your elbows** as your arms travel out to the sides in a wide arc.
* Keep a soft bend in the elbows the entire time; don’t swing your torso.

3. **Raise to shoulder height**

* Exhale as you lift until **wrists, elbows, and shoulders align** (roughly shoulder height).
* Keep thumbs **slightly up/neutral** to give your shoulders room.
* Pause for about **1 second** at the top; neck long, shoulders still depressed.

4. **Lower with control**

* Inhale and lower the bells along the same arc for **2–3 seconds**.
* Stop just before they touch your thighs to keep tension.

5. **Tempo & range**

* Smooth, **no jerking**. If you must swing or shrug, the weight is too heavy.
* Work in a comfortable pain-free range; shoulder height or a touch below is fine.

6. **Programming (quick guide)**

* Beginners: **2–3 sets of 10–15 reps** with light weights.
* Rest **45–75 sec** between sets.

**Common mistakes to avoid**

* Shrugging the shoulders toward your ears.
* Locking or changing the elbow bend mid-rep.
* Turning it into a front raise by drifting hands forward.
* Using momentum (leaning/back swing).

**Cues**

* “Elbows up, shoulders down.”
* “Pour nothing—thumbs slightly up.”
* “Lift wide, lower slow.”

The visual step-by-step image is provided above; these are the matching written steps.

Gemini_text:
Here's how to perform a lateral raise with dumbbells:

1.  **Starting Position:** Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Let your arms hang naturally at your sides, with your palms facing your body. Keep a slight bend in your elbows.
    
2.  **Raise the Dumbbells:** Keeping that slight bend in your elbows, slowly raise the dumbbells out to your sides.
    
3.  **Top Position:** Continue raising until your arms are roughly parallel to the floor, forming a "T" shape with your body. Your pinkies should be slightly higher than your thumbs (as if pouring water from a pitcher). Avoid shrugging your shoulders.

prompt: How to Row on a Rowing Machine? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Sit down on the seat and bend your knees. Make sure your bottom feels comfortable on the seat and adjust yourself if necessary. Bend your knees so you can get closer to the base of the machine. Look for a flat surface near the bottom of the base where you feet will go, which is called the footplate. Then, find the handle that's attached to the cord on the machine. The handle will be in the center of the base or near the top of the base. Be careful as you sit down because the seat slides. 2. Secure the footplate strap around the top of your shoelaces. The balls of your feet are the only area that will maintain constant contact with the footplate, since you’ll likely need to lift your heels when your knees are bent. Pull the straps across the top of your foot until your feet feel secure. Make sure your feet don’t slide around on the footplate as this can mess up your form. It's best to wear rubber-soled shoes like sneakers, running shoes, or cross trainers while you're using a rowing machine. This makes it less likely your feet will slip. Don’t tighten the strap so tightly that it hurts. If your feet feel uncomfortable, loosen the straps and try again. 3. Hold the handle using an overhand grip. The cord on the rowing machine has a handgrip that you’ll pull to work your arms. Grab onto the handle and pull it toward you. Adjust your hands on the handle so that they're in an overhand grip, which means your palms are facing down. Using an underhand grip rotates your arms and increases your risk of injury, so it's best to avoid positioning your hands palms up. 4. Engage your core and straighten your posture. Once you have the handle in your hand, check your posture to make sure your back and shoulders are straight. Tighten your core muscles so they’re working as you row. An engaged core also helps keep your posture straight. You don’t want to slump forward or lean too far back as you’re rowing. 5. Extend your arms and bend your knees to get into “the catch.” In rowing, the starting position is called “the catch.” While it might sound complicated, it’s a really natural pose to begin rowing. Pull the handle to extend the cord toward you, but keep your arms extended out away from your body. Then, bend your knees so that your seat is as close to the base of the machine as possible. When you're in the catch position, make sure your torso is hinged forward at your hips, your arms are straight out in front of you, and your shins are no more than perpendicular to the floor. Don't slide your seat as close to your feet as possible, as this can cause you to lean back. If you start your stroke with your shoulders behind your hips, you'll use your back in your push-off, which weakens your stroke and increases your risk of injury. Remember to keep your core engaged. 6. Push off the footplate with your leg muscles. Your legs will do most of the work during your drives. Use the power you have in your leg muscles to push yourself. Keep your arms and upper body neutral at this time. Your legs should do 60% of the work while rowing. 7. Extend your legs until they’re straight. Roll your feet down onto the footplate so that they’re flat once your legs are fully extended. Flow directly into the upper body shift just before your legs are fully extended. 8. Bend at your hips to push your upper body slightly back. Be very careful with this step because you don’t want to curve your spine. Instead, hinge at your waist so that your entire upper body leans back with your spine straight and your core engaged. As soon as you lean back, start pulling with your arms. Your core will do about 20% of the work during your drive. 9. Pull the grip toward your lower rib cage. The arm motion is the final part of a rowing sequence. Bend your elbows to bring the handle toward you. Keep your wrists straight to protect them from injury. Your arms should provide the final 20% of power to complete your drive. 10. Bring your elbows back behind you as you pull the grip. It’s really important to follow through when you do the arm motion so you get the full upper body workout. When the handle is down at your rib cage, make sure your elbows are angled behind you and not at your sides. Keep them close to your body. This position is called “the finish” because it’s the end of the drive. Check that your legs are extended, your core is engaged, your upper body is leaning slightly back, and your handgrip is just below your rib cage. 11. Extend your arms back in front of you. During your recovery, you’ll reverse the order of the drive. Start by straightening out your elbows to push the handle back out in front of you. Once your arms are extended, go directly into the upper body shift. Remember to keep your wrists straight as you do this. Don’t let go of the handle because the cord on the machine might snap back. 12. Hinge forward at your waist until you’re sitting up straight again. Keep your core engaged as you lean back up. Remember to hinge forward at your waist without curving your spine. Your legs will stay fully extended until you’re sitting back up. 13. Bend your knees to slide back to start. You’re almost there! Release the tension in your legs to slide back toward the base of the machine. Bend your legs as far as you comfortably can to return to “the catch” position. This completes 1 stroke. 14. Go directly into your next stroke if your workout isn't finished. A single stroke on a rowing machine has a drive and a recovery. At first, you might focus on mastering your form without worrying about how many strokes you're doing or how long you're rowing. Later, set a time limit to your workout or set a goal for how many meters you'll row. You might also use a preset rowing machine workout. At first, you might set a goal to row for 10 minutes straight. As the exercise becomes easier for you, try increasing your goal by 10 minutes at a time until you can do a 30 to 40 minute workout on the rowing machine. For an interval workout, you might row 1 minute on and then rest for 1 minute. Do this for 30 to 40 minutes to get a full body workout. You might also set a goal to row 1,000 meters. Once this becomes easy for you, try increasing the distance or doing multiple rounds of 1,000 meters with rests in between.

text_rubrics.criterion: The answer must describe the four main phases of the rowing stroke in the correct order: Catch, Drive, Finish, and Recovery.
The answer must correctly sequence the body movements for the 'Drive' phase: legs first, then core/body, and finally arms.
The answer must correctly sequence the body movements for the 'Recovery' phase, which is the reverse of the drive: arms, then core/body, and finally legs.
The answer must include instructions for initial setup, covering how to sit, secure the feet, and hold the handle (e.g., with an overhand grip).
The answer must emphasize maintaining proper posture and form for safety, such as keeping the back straight and engaging the core.
The instructions provided must be presented as a clear, sequential list of actionable steps.
The answer should specify key body positions at the 'Catch' (e.g., arms straight, shins vertical) and 'Finish' (e.g., handle at lower ribs, slight backward lean).

image_rubrics.criterion: Each image in the sequence must visually represent the primary action described in the corresponding numbered text step.

The images must accurately depict critical form details mentioned in the text to ensure safety and effectiveness, such as maintaining a straight back, hinging at the hips, and proper hand/foot placement.

The complete sequence of images must logically and correctly illustrate the full cycle of a rowing stroke, covering the distinct phases of the catch, drive, finish, and recovery as detailed in the text.

Where applicable, images should use visual aids, such as directional arrows, to clarify the direction of movement being described in the text (e.g., pushing with legs, pulling with arms, leaning back).
For steps that focus on a specific body part (e.g., feet, hands), the image should provide a clear, close-up view that highlights the relevant detail, such as foot strap placement or hand grip.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** (separate from the visual):

# How to Row on a Rowing Machine — Step-by-Step

## 0) Quick setup (1–2 minutes)

1. **Damper/Resistance:** Start light–moderate (on most flywheels, a damper of ~3–5).
2. **Foot stretchers:** Adjust so the strap crosses over the widest part of your foot (around the ball/laces).
3. **Handle & chain:** Keep the chain moving **level**—straight into and out of the machine.
4. **Monitor:** Choose an easy warm-up pace; you’ll focus on form before speed.

---

## The 4 phases of each stroke

Think **Legs → Body → Arms** on the way out, and **Arms → Body → Legs** on the way back.

1. **CATCH (start position)**

   * Shins vertical, heels may lift slightly.
   * Hinge forward at the hips (torso ~11 o’clock), back neutral, shoulders relaxed, arms straight.
   * Eyes forward, grip the handle lightly (no death-grip).

2. **DRIVE (power)**

   * **Push through the legs first**—like a leg press. Arms stay straight; torso still slightly forward.
   * As legs near straight, **pivot the torso** through neutral to a slight lean back (~1 o’clock).
   * Finally, **draw with the arms**, bringing the handle to the lower ribs. Wrists flat.

3. **FINISH (end of drive)**

   * Legs straight (not locked), torso slightly back, elbows past the body, handle at lower ribs.
   * Lats on, shoulders down, core braced. Chain level.

4. **RECOVERY (return)**

   * **Arms away** first until straight → **torso pivots forward** → **knees bend** to slide forward.
   * Glide back to the catch smoothly; this is the long, easy part.
   * Aim for a rhythm of about **1 part drive : 2–3 parts recovery**.

---

## Breathing & Rhythm

* **Exhale** during the drive, **inhale** on the recovery.
* Cadence targets: **18–24 spm** (steady technique work), **24–28 spm** (moderate workouts).

---

## Common form cues

* “Push the machine **away** with your feet.”
* “Chain travels **straight**; keep wrists flat.”
* “Sit tall—**long spine**, relaxed shoulders.”
* “Sequence, don’t rush: **legs → body → arms** / **arms → body → legs**.”

---

## Frequent mistakes to avoid

* Rounding the lower back or hunching shoulders.
* **Early arm pull** (bending elbows before the legs finish).
* **Over-compressing** at the catch (shins past vertical or heels jammed up).
* Slamming knees open or letting them cave in.
* Rushing the slide—make the recovery unhurried.

---

## Quick beginner workout (10 minutes)

* 3 min easy warm-up, practicing the sequence.
* 4 x 1 min moderate / 1 min easy (stay clean on form).
* 2 min easy cool-down with long strokes.

Here's a step-by-step guide on how to use a rowing machine, complete with visuals!

**Step 1: The Catch**
Start in the "catch" position. Your knees should be bent, shins vertical, and arms extended forward, gripping the handle. Lean slightly forward from your hips.

**Step 2: The Drive (Legs)**
Push off with your legs, driving them straight back. Keep your core engaged and arms still extended. This is the most powerful part of the stroke.

**Step 3: The Drive (Hips and Arms)**
Once your legs are almost straight, lean back slightly from your hips and pull the handle towards your upper abdomen/lower chest. Keep your elbows close to your body.

prompt: How to Exercise to Lose Belly Fat? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Walk it off. Walking is a great way to burn fat and work your abdominal muscles. Walk for 30 minutes at least 5 times a week. To burn the most calories, tighten your abdominal muscles while you're walking. Walk at a brisk pace, where you can talk normally but would have trouble singing, and don't forget to swing those arms! If you need to, start out with shorter walks and work your way up to 30 minutes. 2. Take off running to burn fat quickly. If walking seems a bit slow to you, move up to running. Running can burn as many as 600 to 1,000 calories per hour, and best of all, you don't have to hit the gym to run. If you want to increase the intensity, try running up hills. [3] X Expert Source Laura Flinn NASM Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview 3. Hop on a rowing machine to get your heart pumping. Rowing is a great all-body workout, and it gets your blood pumping. Plus, rowing often works muscles that your body isn't accustomed to using, which means it can help ramp up your metabolism. 4. Cycle your fat away. Whether you jump on your bike or hit a cycling class at the gym, cycling is also a great way to burn fat. A cycling class can help you increase your intensity to ensure you're burning as much fat as you can, but you may find it easier to incorporate riding a bike into your routine. For instance, you could bike to work instead of taking your car. 5. Swim laps for an all-body workout. Swimming is a great full-body workout, and you can burn up to 750 calories per hour. Try swimming for 30 to 45 minutes 4 or 5 times per week to get the full benefit. If you're just starting out, start out with 10 laps of 50 metres (160 ft) each. You can rest for about half a minute between laps. Add 100 to 200 metres (330 to 660 ft) per week. 6. Row with intensity training. On the rowing machine, row steadily for 20 seconds, and then rest for 10. As you rest, stay on the machine with your legs and arms in place. On the next 20 seconds, try to beat your last 20 seconds. Keep going for 8 rounds of 20 seconds of rowing and 10 seconds of rest. With each round, work on beating your last distance. Finish up by rowing for 500 meters. 7. Sprint using HIIT. As an example of a HIIT routine, you could run and coast at given intervals. For instance, you can run for 40 yards all-out, then slow down for 40 yards. Rest for half a minute and begin again. Alternatively, you can run for 30 seconds and rest for 1 minute and 15 seconds, repeating 10 times. 8. Switch between muscle groups. Typically with interval training, you work hard for a short period and then take a rest. However, another way you can do it is to switch between muscle groups without taking a rest. For instance, focus on an exercise that works your legs and then jump into an exercise that primarily works your arms. For instance, try 30 seconds of pull-ups, doing as many as you can, followed by 60 jumping jacks and 20 burpees, then rest for 30 seconds.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** to go with the visual:

1. Warm-Up (5–10 min)

* Dynamic moves to raise heart rate and prep joints: brisk walk or march in place, arm circles, leg swings, hip circles.
* Aim to feel warm, not tired.

2. Interval Cardio (15–25 min, 2–4×/week)

* Pick any modality you like (walk/jog, bike, rower).
* After 5 min easy, do 8–12 rounds: **1 min hard (RPE 7–8/10)** + **1–2 min easy**.
* Beginners: brisk walk hills; advanced: short sprints. Consistency beats intensity.

3. Strength + Core Circuit (20–30 min, 2–4×/week)
   Complete 3 rounds, resting 60–90s between moves:

* Squat or goblet squat — 10–12 reps
* Hip hinge (dumbbell/kettlebell deadlift) — 10–12
* Push (push-ups or DB press) — 8–12
* Pull (rows or pulldowns) — 10–12
* Core: plank 30–45s or dead bug 8–10/side
  Progress each week (more reps, weight, or an extra round).

4. Cooldown & Consistency (5–10 min + daily habits)

* Easy stretching and deep breathing.
* Move daily: aim 7–10k steps. Sleep 7–9h, hydrate.
* Do Steps 2–3 on **3–5 days/week**. Remember: you **can’t spot-reduce**—fat loss comes from total activity + time.

If you’d like, I can tailor the plan to your equipment, fitness level, or schedule.

Gemini_text:
Losing belly fat involves a combination of targeted exercises and a healthy diet. Here are some exercises that can help, along with visual aids for each step:

### Exercises to Lose Belly Fat

**1. Crunches**
Crunches are a classic abdominal exercise that helps strengthen your core muscles.
*   **Step 1:** Lie down on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands behind your head or across your chest. *   **Step 2:** Exhale and contract your abdominal muscles to lift your head and shoulders off the floor. Hold for a second, then slowly lower back down. Repeat 10-15 times for 3 sets. **2. Russian Twists**
Russian twists target the obliques and help tighten the waistline.
*   **Step 1:** Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat, leaning back slightly to engage your core. You can hold a weight or medicine ball for added intensity. *   **Step 2:** Twist your torso to the right, bringing the weight towards the floor beside you. Then twist to the left. Alternate sides for 10-12 twists per side, for 3 sets.

prompt: How to do standing calf raises on a step? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Stand on the edge of a stair step, or a step of any kind (as long as it's in a safe environment). Make sure the step is not very far up and close to the ground. You don't want to fall too far should you lose your balance . 2. Stand straight, with your tailbone tucked in. Engage your core by pulling in your upper ribs and belly. Make sure that the balls of your feet are solidly planted on the edge of the step. Your heels should be over the edge. If you feel unstable, or like you're losing your balance, practice this method with a wall or railing near by. Place your hands on the wall or the railing. 3. Lift your heels until you're standing on your tippy toes. Distribute most of your weight onto the balls of your feet, and keep your legs straight. 4. Stay on your tippy toes for two seconds. Then, begin to lower your heels, and move your weight away from the balls of your feet. Lower your heels until they're below the step, or platform. You should be feeling your calf muscles stretch on the downward movement. Repeat this sequence until you feel tired.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** to go with the visual:

1. Setup

* Stand on a sturdy step with the **balls of your feet** on the edge and **heels hanging off**.
* Feet hip-width, toes pointing straight ahead.
* Lightly hold a wall/rail for balance. **Soft knees**, chest tall, core braced.

2. Lower (stretch)

* **Slowly** drop your heels below the step until you feel a gentle calf stretch.
* Keep ankles neutral—don’t let them **roll inward** (no “caving”).

3. Raise (drive up)

* Press through the balls of your feet and lift your heels as **high as possible**.
* Keep weight over the **big toe and second toe**.
* **Do not bounce**—move smoothly.

4. Peak squeeze

* At the top, **pause 1 second** and squeeze your calves.

5. Lower with control

* Take **~3 seconds** to lower back to just below step height.
* Maintain posture and ankle alignment. That’s 1 rep.
* Suggested tempo: **1 up – 1 hold – 3 down**.

Programming & tips

* **Sets/Reps:** 3 sets of **8–15** controlled reps.
* **Breathing:** Exhale up, inhale down.
* **Range:** Go through your full pain-free range; skip deep stretch if it pinches the Achilles.
* **Progressions:**

  * Make it harder: do **single-leg** calf raises or hold a dumbbell.
  * Make it easier: reduce range (stop at step height) or keep both hands on support.
* **Common mistakes:** bouncing, locking knees, letting ankles cave, turning toes out, leaning forward.

If you’d like the graphic as a printable PDF or with your gym’s colors/logo, I can generate that too.

prompt: How to do a face pull with resistance band? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Find a cable pulley machine. The best equipment for a face pull is a cable pulley machine, which should be available at any local gym. A cable pulley machine is a tall piece of exercise equipment with a series of weights attached to an adjustable pulley designed for exercising muscles in your arms and back. It will allow you to easily adjust the size of the weight you’ll be lifting, as well as the height of the pulley mechanism. If you don’t have access to a cable pulley machine, you can use a long resistance band attached to something sturdy a little above the height of your head. This will be less customizable than the cable pulley machine but may be easier to access on a regular basis. 2. Equip the rope attachment. The rope attachment for the cable pulley machine is a short length of rope with a weight on either end and a point to attach it in the middle. Open the carabiner on the machine and clip on the rope attachment. Always take care of the equipment you’re using. If there’s a different attachment already on the machine, make sure to put it back with the other attachments when you equip the rope attachment. 3. Adjust the pulley to be a little above the height of your head. There will normally be a handle or some other mechanism on the side of the pulley rig that you can disengage and engage to adjust the height of the pulley. Shift the pulley so that it is just above the height of your head before locking it in place. 4. Equip a weight around 30 pounds. Face pulls don’t require a heavy weight in order to get the workout you need. Adjust the pin on the weights so that you can easily lift them with only the movement of your arms.The right weight will change from person to person, so start around 30 pounds (14 kg) and add more weight as needed. If you try and do a face pull with too much weight equipped, you’ll end up engaging muscles in your arms and lower back and increase the risk of injury. 5. Grasp one end of the rope in each hand. Firmly grasp the ends of the rope so that the weights on either end face toward you. Take a few steps backward until your arms are fully extended toward the machine. 6. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart and your knees bent. Find a firm stance with your knees slightly bent so that you won’t be pulled around by the machine. Lean back around 20 degrees so all of the work is being done by your arms and shoulders rather than your back. If you find this stance difficult to maintain or start feeling pain in your lower back as you exercise, you might need to adjust your stance. Try shifting to a slightly staggered stance with one foot behind the other. 7. Pull the ropes towards your face. Pull the two ropes toward your face, separating your hands and moving them around the side of your head as they get close. Don't raise or pinch the shoulders together—instead, broaden your shoulders as your elbows drive back. [11] X Expert Source Monica Morris ACE Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview When holding onto the ropes, rotate your arms at a 90-degree angle. Your elbows should be positioned at shoulder height as you pull the ropes. [12] X Expert Source Monica Morris ACE Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview Always keep your elbows high and your wrists above your elbows when pulling the rope backward. Straying too much from this can change the muscles being targeted by the exercise. 8. Reverse the movement and repeat. Hold the ropes on either side of your face for around 1 second, before slowly returning to your initial position by reversing the pulling movement. [14] X Expert Source Monica Morris ACE Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview Take about 8 seconds to the control the negative when returning the ropes to the beginning position. [16] X Expert Source Monica Morris ACE Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview As face pulls are designed to slowly exercise your muscles with lighter weights, you should do two sets of 20 reps at the end of a back workout. Over time, you may need to add more weight, but you shouldn't need to add more reps or sets. 9. Exercise your rear deltoids and trapezius muscles. Face pulls are designed to work the muscles in and around the shoulder blades, so you should be feeling the exercise here rather than anywhere else. If you are working your biceps or lower back instead, revisit your posture, stance and underhand grip until you feel it in your shoulders. [18] X Expert Source Monica Morris ACE Certified Personal Trainer Expert Interview 10. Move slowly for each rep. It’s more important to move slowly and make sure you are exercising the right muscles than to power through quickly and risk injury. Do a set of around 20 reps slowly, making sure to pull the ropes all way back and fully stretch your rear delts each time. 11. Lean backward rather than forward. As you work through your face pulls, you might feel yourself starting to lean forward while you pull. This might indicate that you have equipped too many weights or are working the wrong muscles. Always make sure you are leaning slightly backward rather than forward. 12. Check that your form is correct. To make sure your form stays correct as you face pull, get a friend or trainer to keep an eye on you and make sure you’re not making any mistakes. You can also set up a camera or leave your phone to record you exercising. You can then review the footage after each set and see where you might be able to revise your form.

The instructions must describe the initial setup, including how to anchor the resistance band to a sturdy object at an appropriate height (e.g., at or just above head level).
The answer must detail the correct starting stance and posture, such as foot placement, having a slight bend in the knees, and leaning back slightly.

For text steps that describe concepts rather than physical movements (e.g., muscles targeted, checking form), the corresponding image should provide a relevant conceptual illustration, like an anatomical diagram or a depiction of the scenario.

GPT_text:
# Text steps: Face Pull with a Resistance Band

1. **Anchor the band**
   Fix it at roughly **face height** (door anchor or sturdy post). Test that it’s secure.

2. **Grip & stance**
   Hold the band ends (or rope handles) with a **neutral or overhand grip**, thumbs pointing up.
   Take a **small step back** until there’s light tension with your **arms straight**.
   Feet shoulder-width (or a light stagger). **Ribs down, glutes lightly on, head neutral.**

3. **Set your shoulders**
   Draw shoulder blades **down and back** (don’t shrug). Brace your midline.

4. **Start position**
   Raise elbows to **about shoulder height** (slightly below is fine). Wrists straight, forearms vertical.

5. **Pull**
   Initiate with your **shoulder blades** (retract), then pull the band toward your **eyes/upper face**.
   Elbows travel **out and back**; let the hands separate slightly so you get a bit of **external rotation** (think *thumbs toward ears*).

6. **Peak squeeze**
   Pause **1–2 seconds** when your hands are beside your face. Feel rear delts, mid-back, and rotator cuff working.

7. **Controlled return**
   Slowly **extend** your arms forward until elbows are nearly straight, keeping your shoulders set. Maintain tension—don’t let the band yank you.

8. **Breathing & tempo**
   **Exhale** as you pull, **inhale** on the way out.
   Use a **2–1–2** tempo: 2s pull, 1s hold, 2s return.

9. **Sets & reps**
   Do **2–4 sets of 10–15 reps**, 2–3×/week. Step closer/farther or switch band thickness to adjust difficulty.

### Quick form checks

* Don’t **shrug** or arch your lower back.
* Keep **forearms vertical** and **wrists neutral**.
* Pull to **eye/upper-face level**, not your chest.
* Anchor should be **face height**; too low makes you shrug.

### Friendly progressions

* **Half-kneeling** (front knee down) if you tend to arch your back.
* **Single-arm** face pulls to fix side-to-side imbalances.

If you want, I can regenerate the visual with a different style (photo, color, or single long strip).

Gemini_text:
Here are the steps to perform a face pull with a resistance band, accompanied by visuals:

**Step 1: Anchor the Band**
Secure your resistance band to a sturdy anchor point at approximately chest height. This could be a door frame, a pole, or a piece of gym equipment. Ensure it's stable and won't detach during the exercise.
**Step 2: Grip the Band**
Stand facing the anchor point, taking a few steps back to create tension in the band. Grip the ends of the band with an overhand grip, palms facing down, or a neutral grip, palms facing each other. Your hands should be shoulder-width apart.
**Step 3: Initiate the Pull**
Engage your core and pull the band towards your face. Your elbows should lead the movement, flaring out to the sides and up. Aim to bring your hands to either side of your head, near your ears.
**Step 4: Squeeze and Hold**
At the peak of the movement, squeeze your shoulder blades together and hold for a brief moment. You should feel the contraction in your upper back and rear deltoids.
**Step 5: Control the Return**
Slowly and with control, extend your arms back to the starting position, resisting the pull of the band. Do not let the band snap back quickly. Maintain tension throughout the entire movement.

prompt: How to do a back extension on a bench? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Start in a squatting position. Bend your knees and come close to the floor, almost as though you are going to sit. Hover just above the ground, with your thighs hugging close to your calves. As you get more comfortable with this move, you can start from a standing squat. Eventually you will start from a completely standing position. 2. Round your back. Bend your elbows close to your body so that your hands are by your ears. Tuck your head between your arms and curl your back forwards. As you get more comfortable with the position, you can start with your hands extended out in front of you. 3. Roll backwards. When your head hits the mat, tuck your chin and push the ground with your hands. Think about pushing your body away from the mat with your hands. Be sure to keep your shoulders and arms strong and close to your head. They are your point of strength. 4. Swing your legs over your head. Using the momentum of your legs and the strength of your arms, bring your legs over your head and your feet to the mat. You may have to use your core strength as well. Kick your legs to gain momentum, but squeeze your abs to pull your feet to the mat. 5. Stand up. Once your feet hit the mat, press against the mat with your hands, pushing your upper body up to follow your feet. You will be in a squat with your hands on the mat. Stand up from there, with your arms up. In order to practice for your back extension, you can practice ending in a pushup position instead of a standing position. When your feet hit the mat, press against the mat with your hands and use your ab muscles to straighten out into a plank position. Hold that position to build strength.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** (separate from the image):

1. **Set up the bench**

   * Use a Roman-chair/hyperextension bench.
   * Adjust the hip/thigh pad so the top edge sits just below your hip bones (ASIS). Your torso should hinge freely at the hips.
   * Lock your ankles under the pads with feet flat on the plate, legs straight but knees soft.

2. **Starting position**

   * Body in a straight line from head to heels; ribs stacked over pelvis.
   * Cross arms over your chest (easiest). Keep neck neutral (gaze ~1–2 m ahead of the floor).

3. **Brace**

   * Inhale through the nose; lightly brace your abs and squeeze your glutes to set a neutral spine.

4. **Lower (the hinge)**

   * Hinge at the hips and **control** the descent. Let the torso tip forward while keeping your back neutral (don’t round).
   * Stop when you feel a hamstring stretch or when your torso is slightly below parallel. Tempo idea: ~2–3 seconds down.

5. **Pause**

   * Brief 1-second pause at the bottom while staying tight; keep shoulders away from ears.

6. **Raise**

   * Drive your hips into the pad, squeeze glutes/hamstrings, and lift the torso until it’s **in line** with your legs.
   * Exhale as you come up. Do **not** hyperextend or arch past straight.

7. **Finish & repeat**

   * Hold the top for half a second in neutral, then repeat for 8–12 smooth reps.

**Progressions & variations**

* Easier: hands on hips → arms across chest.
* Harder: hands behind head → hold a light plate/dumbbell tight to chest.
* Tempo challenge: 3–4 sec down, 2-sec pause at bottom, 1 sec up.
* Range: only as deep as you can keep a neutral spine.

**Common mistakes to avoid**

* Rounding the lower back on the way down.
* Throwing the torso/swinging to get up.
* Hyperextending at the top (arching past a straight line).
* Pad set too high (blocks the hips) or too low (digs into thighs).
* Craning the neck up; keep it neutral.

**Safety tips**

* If you feel sharp pain (especially in the lower back), stop.
* Keep motion at the **hips**, not by bending the spine.
* Start with bodyweight and perfect control before adding load.

If you want, I can also give steps for a **flat-bench alternative** (no Roman chair) or tailor reps/sets to your program.

Gemini_text:
Here's how to perform a back extension on a bench, with visual steps:

1.  **Position Yourself:** Lie face down on a back extension bench, ensuring your hips are positioned just above the pad. Your feet should be securely anchored under the foot pads, and your upper body should be able to hang freely.
    2.  **Starting Position:** Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands lightly behind your head (do not pull on your neck). Your body should form a straight line from your ankles to your shoulders.
    3.  **Lowering Phase:** Slowly lower your upper body towards the floor by hinging at your hips. Keep your back straight and controlled throughout the movement. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings and glutes.
    4.  **Extension Phase:** Engage your glutes and lower back muscles to raise your upper body back to the starting position. Focus on squeezing your back muscles at the top of the movement. Avoid hyperextending your spine past a straight line.
