prompt: How to do a side leg raise lying down? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Lie on your right side with your hips and feet stacked. Extend out straight on the floor, bending your elbow to rest your head on the hand of your lower arm. You can put your upper arm in front of you with your palm flat on the floor for support. If you feel unstable laying this way, bracing the soles of your feet against a wall will help you feel more secure. Another way to increase your stability is to bend your lower knee at a 90-degree angle. Your top leg should still be extended straight out. [3] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source 2. Lift your top leg until you feel your hips begin to tilt. Lift your leg slowly with control as high as you comfortably can without tilting your hips or rolling forward. Keep your body in a straight line and activate your glutes to help you lift your leg. Don't focus on how high you can lift your leg. To work your glutes, you need to keep your hips as straight as possible. If you're rolling forward to lift your leg higher, you're not getting the full benefit. 3. Lower your leg back to starting position. Pause for a second with your leg raised, then slowly lower it back down. Control the movement, resisting the weight of your leg, rather than simply letting it fall. Stopping your foot before you reach your other foot and leaving it hovering in the lower position keeps your glutes activated between reps. 4. Complete 8-10 reps, then switch sides for 1 set. Continue raising and lowering your leg with controlled movements. Make sure you don't start tilting forward or get sloppy with your form. Then roll over to do the same number of reps on the other side. [6] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source The number of sets you do depends on your overall level of fitness. If you're just starting out, you might only be able to do 1 set. Add another set every couple of weeks to continue to challenge yourself as you get stronger. 5. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then extend your right leg. Start with good posture, standing straight up with your feet in line with your hips. Point your right toe and slide your foot out to the side until your hips are level. Make sure when you do this you're still standing straight, not leaning over. 6. Raise your right leg to the side as high as you can. Lift your leg out to the side in a slow, controlled movement until you feel the oblique muscle on the side of your torso contract. You'll also feel a nice stretch down the back of your thigh. It's important to keep your torso straight and maintain good posture. If you find it difficult to balance, use a table or the back of a sturdy chair for stability. 7. Return your leg to the starting position. Hold your leg at the highest lift point for a second, then slowly lower it. Control the movement by resisting the weight of your leg rather than simply dropping it to the ground. Keep your toes pointed as you bring your leg back down. If you want to make the exercise a little more difficult, stop when your toes are hovering just above the floor rather than going all the way down to touch the floor. 8. Complete 8-10 reps, then switch sides. Maintain good posture while completing your reps, taking care not to start leaning to the side or tilting your hips. Square up your feet under your hips, point your left toes, and repeat the exercise with your left leg. If you're doing interval training, you can also add side leg raises to your routine, doing as many as you can in 45-60 seconds. Instead of doing all the reps and then switching sides, you can also alternate between sides. Just make sure you're maintaining good form.

GPT_text:
Here are the text steps (separate from the visual):

1. Setup

* Lie on your side with legs straight, hips and shoulders stacked.
* Rest your head on your lower arm; place top hand on floor in front of your torso.
* Draw your belly button gently in to brace; keep your top foot flexed (toes toward shin).

2. Lift

* Without rolling your pelvis, raise the top leg in a straight line 12–18 inches (about 30–45°).
* Keep hips stacked, knee pointing forward, ankle neutral.

3. Hold

* Pause for 1–2 seconds at the top.
* Keep your core engaged and ribs down; avoid arching your back or turning the toes up.

4. Lower

* Slowly lower the leg with control to just above the bottom leg; don’t let it thud.
* Breathe out on the way down. Repeat for 8–15 reps, then switch sides.

Tips: Move smoothly, not fast. If you feel it in your low back, lower your range or bend the bottom knee for balance. Add a mini-band above the knees for extra challenge.

prompt: How to Do Butt Kicks? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Keep your back straight and your knees slightly bent. Let your arms hang by your side or bend your elbows like you would if you were jogging. 2. Take deep belly breaths through your nose. It’s important to breathe properly during any sort of exercise. As a rule, it’s best to exhale during the part of the movement where your muscles are doing the most work. [2] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Breathe in as you get ready to kick, then breathe out when you lift your leg up and back. Breathe in again as you lower your leg. If you have trouble remembering when to breathe, memorize the phrase “Exhale on Exertion.” 3. Bend your knee and swing your foot up and back. Try to touch your heel with your butt. If you can’t quite reach your butt, don’t worry—just get as close as you can! When you’re done, bring your foot back down to the floor. Touch down lightly on the ball of your foot. Keep your hips and shoulders square, and make sure your leg swings straight back instead of out to the side. 4. Kick your other foot up to your opposite glute. Keep switching back and forth between your legs. Stick to a slow, easy pace at first so you can focus on form. 5. Swing your opposite arm forward as you kick up your leg. This will increase the intensity of the exercise a little. Bend your arms 90° at each elbow, just like you would if you were running or jogging. 6. Gradually speed up until you’re at a jog. Do quick alternating steps for 20-60 seconds to get your blood pumping. Don’t forget to pump your arms at the same time! While you’re still learning how to do butt kicks, focus on proper form instead of speed. For example, you might do 20 or 30 reps without worrying about how long it takes to complete the set. As you pick up speed, keep focusing on form. Keep your back straight and your shoulders and hips square. When you’re using butt kicks as part of a dynamic warmup, aim to do them for about a minute before moving on to another stretch or exercise. 7. This will increase the intensity and the fun level. Start out at a jogging pace with your arms bent at your sides. Then, alternate raising your arms to the ceiling and bringing them down to your sides with every kick. Turn on some lively workout music and kick along to the beat! 8. Try this to improve your running posture and technique. Instead of swinging your heel up and around to kick the back of your butt, pull it straight up beneath you. Try to touch the bottom of your butt, where you feel your ischium (or “sit bone”). In this variant, your knee will stick out slightly in front of you as you complete the kick, rather than pointing down at the ground. Focus on letting each foot land softly instead of stomping down hard when you complete the kick. 9. Turn your butt kicks into a dynamic running drill. Instead of standing in one place as you do your kicks, jog forward. As you lift each leg off the ground, bend your knee sharply to kick your heel back toward your glute. Land on the balls of your feet. Running butt kicks are a great way to get more spring in your step and improve the form of your footfalls for better shock absorption. This exercise is also great for strengthening your quadriceps (a group of muscles in the front of your thigh). 10. Butt kicks work best when combined with other warmups. Before you start running or doing any other cardio exercise, spend 5 minutes doing dynamic stretches and exercises, including butt kicks. To target other muscles in your legs and improve your flexibility, try a routine that also includes about 1 minute each of: Rotation running. Jog straight ahead, but twist your torso around to look behind you every 2-3 steps. Walking or jogging backwards. High knees. Bring your knees up toward your chest as you jog forward or in place. Side shuffles. Stand with your shoulders and hips square and move sideways, springing lightly off the balls of your feet. Cariocas. Run sideways while alternately crossing your legs in front of each other.

GPT_text:
# Text Steps: Butt Kicks

1. Start tall

* Feet hip-width, arms bent ~90°.
* Brace your core, eyes forward.

2. Kick the right heel to the right glute

* Knee points down (don’t lift thigh high).
* Land softly on the ball of the left foot.
* Opposite arm swings forward naturally.

3. Switch legs quickly

* Left heel to left glute while the right foot steps forward.
* Keep chest up and torso stacked over hips.

4. Find a light rhythm

* Alternate legs like a gentle jog in place.
* Quick, small steps; heels “tap” the glutes.
* Breathe steady.

### Cues

* “Tall and soft.”
* “Knees down, heels up.”
* “Quick, quiet feet.”

### Common mistakes to avoid

* Leaning backward or arching the low back.
* Letting knees lift high in front (that’s high knees, not butt kicks).
* Slamming heels or overstriding.

### Sets & timing

* Beginner: 2 × 20–30 seconds (easy pace)
* Intermediate: 3 × 30–45 seconds
* Advanced/conditioning: 4 × 45–60 seconds or 2–3 × 100 meters

### Variations

* Low-impact: Marching butt kicks (no bounce).
* Travel: Move forward with small steps.
* Warm-up combo: 20s butt kicks → 20s high knees → repeat.

If you want me to tailor pacing for a specific sport or warm-up, tell me what you’re training for!

Gemini_text:
Butt kicks are a great cardio exercise that can also help improve your running form. Here's how to do them:

**Step 1: Starting Position**
Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and your arms bent at your sides, similar to a running position. Your core should be engaged and your gaze forward.
**Step 2: Kick Your Heel Up**
In a quick, explosive movement, kick one heel up towards your glutes. Try to actually "kick your butt" with your heel if you can. As you do this, pump the opposite arm forward, just like you would when running.
**Step 3: Alternate Legs**
Quickly lower your foot back to the ground and immediately repeat the motion with the other leg, kicking the other heel towards your glutes and pumping the opposite arm.
**Step 4: Maintain Rhythm**
Continue alternating legs, aiming for a consistent and quick rhythm. Keep your core tight, chest up, and try to avoid leaning back. The movement should primarily come from your legs.

prompt: How to Perform a Hamstring Curl? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Lie on the floor. To do a hamstring curl on the floor, lie on your stomach with your hands in front of you, slightly wider than your shoulders. 2. Lift your feet. From this position, lift one or both feet off the floor by bending your knees. When doing this, you should be keeping your knees on the floor. Keep your back straight and your knees close together throughout the repetition. 3. Straighten your legs. Release your hamstring by lowering your feet back to the floor. From here, repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions, about 12-15 if you're a beginner. [2] X Expert Source Danny Gordon Certified Fitness Coach Expert Interview 4. Add weight. If these are too easy and you don’t notice the contraction in your hamstrings, add some weight. You can do this by either wrapping ankle weights around your lower legs, or by holding a dumbbell between your feet as you lift them off the ground. 5. Find the machine. The hamstring curl machine will have stacked weights on one side, a flat bench for your body, and a padded cylinder for you to move with your legs. 6. Adjust the lever. Laying on your stomach, the padded cylinder behind you should go on top of your legs. The pad should hit just a few inches below your calf muscles. You can adjust it using the lever until it is in the right spot for your height. 7. Keep your torso flat. Tighten your core muscles to help you keep your torso flat on the bench. Ensure your legs are fully stretched in the starting position, and grab the handles in front of your shoulders to steady yourself. 8. Exhale and curl. As you breathe out, curl your legs up as far as possible without lifting your upper legs off of the bench. Hold for a second once you reach the fully contracted position. If it is too easy or too hard, you can stop and adjust the weight using the stack next to you. 9. Inhale and release. As you breathe in, bring your legs slowly back down to your starting position. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions, or 12-15 if you're a beginner. [6] X Expert Source Danny Gordon Certified Fitness Coach Expert Interview 10. Find a swiss ball. Those are the oversized, light, rubber balls often used for Pilates. It doesn’t matter which size you use. Choose one that you’re comfortable with. You’ll get a bigger contraction with a larger ball. 11. Lay on the floor. With your back on the floor, roll the ball up under your feet. You want your feet to be on the top center of the ball. 12. Lift your hips. Put your full weight between your feet (on the ball) and your shoulder blades. Use your arms to stabilize yourself. This will be your starting position. 13. Bring the ball towards you. Bend your knees, pulling the ball as close as you can to your bottom. This will contract the hamstring. Hold for a brief pause and then push the ball back out to your starting position. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions. Do about 12-15 reps when you're just getting started with hamstring curls. [9] X Expert Source Danny Gordon Certified Fitness Coach Expert Interview

GPT_text:
Here are clear, text-only steps for a **Seated Hamstring Curl (machine)**. I’ll generate a separate visual guide next.

# Text Steps

1. Adjust

* Seat so your knees align with the machine’s pivot.
* Backrest supports your lower back.
* Ankle pad sits just above your heels (low calf).

2. Setup

* Sit tall; ribs down, core braced, hips and back glued to the pad.
* Feet hip-width; **toes pulled up** (dorsiflex). Grip the handles.

3. Initiate the curl

* Exhale and **drive your heels down and back**.
* Keep knees pinned to the pad; don’t let hips lift or back arch.

4. Peak squeeze

* Stop when calves near hamstrings (before hips tilt).
* Hold the squeeze ~1 second; keep toes up.

5. Lower under control

* Inhale and **slowly** return to almost straight legs without locking knees.
* Aim for ~3–4 seconds on the way down.

6. Finish & repeat

* Re-brace, keep pelvis heavy on the seat, repeat for reps.

**Programming:** 3–4 sets × 8–12 reps (muscle/strength) or 12–15 (accessory). Rest 60–90s.
**Pro cues:** “Heels to butt,” “toes up,” “ribs down,” “control the return.”
**Common mistakes:** Hips lifting off seat, arching lower back, letting the pad slam, pointing toes, knees flaring way out.
**No machine?** Do a **stability-ball ham curl**: bridge hips up, heels on ball, curl it toward glutes, control out.

The hamstring curl is an isolation exercise that targets the hamstrings, the muscles on the back of your thighs. Here's how to perform it effectively:

1.  **Lie face down on the hamstring curl machine.** Position your body so that your knees are just off the edge of the pad and your ankles are hooked underneath the lever pad. Adjust the machine so the pad rests just above your Achilles tendon. 2.  **Grip the handles** provided on the machine for stability. Ensure your body is stable and ready to execute the movement. 3.  **Flex your knees** and pull your heels towards your glutes, feeling the contraction in your hamstrings. Exhale as you curl the weight up. Focus on squeezing your hamstrings at the peak of the movement. 4.  **Slowly extend your legs** back to the starting position, controlling the weight as you do so. Inhale during this eccentric phase. Avoid letting the weight simply drop.

prompt: How to do a standing quad stretch? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and your hands by your sides. 2. Lift your left foot up and grab it with your left hand. Gently bring your left heel towards your butt while keeping your left thigh perpendicular to the ground. 3. Gently bring your left heel towards your butt while keeping your left thigh perpendicular to the ground.

The answer must include details for effective and safe stretching, such as holding the stretch for a duration (e.g., 10-30 seconds) and repeating on the other leg.

GPT_text:
Here are the text steps (separate from the image):

1. Start tall
   Stand with feet hip-width apart, core gently engaged, shoulders relaxed. If needed, stand next to a wall or chair for balance.

2. Set the stretch
   Shift weight to your left foot. Bend your right knee and reach your right hand back to hold the top of your right foot or ankle. Keep your right knee pointing straight down.

3. Align and deepen
   Bring your thighs together (knees side by side). Keep your pelvis neutral (avoid arching your low back) and stand tall through the chest. Lightly press your foot into your hand until you feel a stretch along the front of the right thigh.

4. Hold and switch
   Breathe and hold 20–30 seconds without pain, keeping hips square and knee pointing downward. Release gently and repeat on the other side.

Tips: If you can’t reach your foot, loop a towel or strap around it. Keep the knee under the hip (not flared out), and avoid pulling the heel past a comfortable range.

prompt: How to do cat-cow yoga pose? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Start on your hands and knees. The starting position for cat pose is also called "tabletop pose." Get on all fours with your wrists directly below your shoulders and your knees directly below your hips. Lay down a yoga mat to lessen the stress on your knees and wrists. Your back should be flat and neutral. Extend your neck out as well, lowering your gaze a bit, so that you can draw a straight, flat line from your head to your tailbone. 2. Spread your fingers. To lessen the stress on your joints, spread your fingers wide and cup your palms slightly. Your middle finger should be facing forward, the rest of your fingers splayed. Press all five fingertips into the mat. If you have problems with your wrists or have had a recent wrist injury, you may want to come down to your elbows. Keep your elbows directly below your shoulders and rest on your forearms instead of your hands. 3. Connect with your breathing. Your breath is a major part of yoga practice. While in tabletop position, take a moment to turn your mental focus to your breath. Inhale deeply through the nose, filling your lungs. Pause, then exhale slowly and deeply out your mouth. 4. Round your back. On an exhale, round your spine up towards the ceiling, keeping your tailbone tucked under. Round your shoulders back so that your shoulder blades fall in line alongside your spine. This position gives the cat pose its name. With your back rounded on all fours, you should look somewhat like an angry cat. 5. Tuck your chin towards your chest. Lengthen your neck to complete cat pose, but don't try to force your chin to touch your chest. Imagine your spine is one long, even curve from your tailbone to your head. Breathe deeply into the curve, gently contracting your glutes. Pull your abdominal muscles back and in towards your spine as you inhale. As you exhale, think of curving and lifting your spine towards the ceiling. Hold the stretch for 5 to 10 breath cycles. 6. Sit back to release. If you're only doing cat pose and not moving into another pose immediately, first lower and flatten your spine to return to tabletop position. Then lower your hips on an exhale to sit back on your heels.

The answer must detail the 'Cow' pose, explaining the action of dropping the belly towards the floor while lifting the chest and tailbone, and linking this movement to an inhale.

GPT_text:
Here are the two parts you asked for—first the **visual**, then the **text**.

# Visual (step-by-step)

I made a clean, poster-style walkthrough of Cat–Cow you can save or print:
**A_four-step_instructional_illustration_on_a_light_.png**

# Text (step-by-step)

1. Start in Tabletop (Neutral)

* Hands under shoulders, knees under hips.
* Spread fingers; press through palms and knuckles.
* Spine long and neutral; gaze down between hands.
* Engage low belly lightly to support your back.

2. Inhale → Cow (Bitilasana)

* Tilt pelvis forward (sit bones lift).
* Let belly soften toward the mat.
* Draw chest through the arms; shoulder blades gently squeeze together.
* Keep neck long; gaze slightly forward (not cranked up).

3. Exhale → Cat (Marjaryasana)

* Press palms; round the entire spine.
* Tuck tailbone; draw navel toward spine.
* Broaden across shoulder blades.
* Let head drop, chin toward chest without jamming.

4. Flow

* Continue to alternate: Inhale to Cow, Exhale to Cat.
* Move slowly with your breath for 5–10 rounds (or ~1–2 minutes).

Tips for Alignment & Comfort

* Keep elbows straight but soft (don’t hyperextend).
* Distribute weight evenly between hands and knees.
* If wrists feel tender, come onto fists or place a folded towel under heels of hands.
* For sensitive knees, add padding under knees or practice on a thicker mat.
* Neck care: the lift in Cow comes from the upper back/chest, not cranking the head up.

Progressions & Options

* Add small hip circles between Cat and Cow to mobilize the spine.
* Pause for 2–3 breaths in whichever shape feels best today.
* To finish, return to neutral or sit back in Child’s Pose for a few breaths.

Breathe easy and move smoothly—quality over range. If you want, I can also generate a print-friendly black-and-white version or separate images for each step.

Gemini_text:
Here are the steps to perform the Cat-Cow yoga pose, along with visual aids:

1.  **Starting Position (Tabletop):** Begin on your hands and knees, with your wrists directly under your shoulders and your knees directly under your hips. Your fingers should be spread wide, and your back should be flat like a tabletop. 2.  **Cow Pose (Inhale):** As you inhale, drop your belly towards the mat, lift your chest and tailbone towards the ceiling, and gently look up. Keep your shoulders rolled away from your ears.  

3.  **Cat Pose (Exhale):** As you exhale, round your spine towards the ceiling, drawing your belly button towards your spine. Let your head drop, bringing your chin towards your chest. Imagine a cat stretching its back. 4.  **Flow:** Continue to flow between Cat and Cow poses, coordinating your movement with your breath. Inhale into Cow, exhale into Cat. Repeat for 5-10 breaths, or as long as feels comfortable.

prompt: How to Do the Surya Namaskar? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Start with the mountain pose . This pose is also known as the Tadasana Namaskar. Stand up straight and tall with your feet planted firmly on the floor, hip-distance apart. Balance your weight evenly on both feet. Let your hands hang at your sides with the palms facing forward and the fingers open, in a receiving position. Alternatively, you can bring your hands together in front of your chest in a prayer position. Press the tips of your thumbs against your sternum, over your heart chakra. Once you are in the mountain pose, breathe slowly and steadily, and focus on finding your center. 2. Raise your arms in an upward salute (Urdhva Hastasana). Inhale deeply and look upward. Slowly raise your arms above your head with the palms together and your fingers pointing straight upward. Push your hips forward a little so that you enter a slight backbend. Keep your shoulders back and down while you are in this pose. 3. Move into a standing forward bend (Uttanasana). Exhale and bend forward at the hips, keeping your back and legs straight. If you can, bring your chest against your thighs and aim the crown of your head at the floor. Place your hands flat on the floor, or rest them on a block if you cannot reach the floor. Try to line your fingertips up with your toes, with your hands positioned on the outsides of your feet. Keep your back as straight as possible while you are in this pose. Your back should not be rounded. 4. Enter a half-standing forward bend (Ardha Uttanasana). Inhale and slowly slide your hands up along your shins. Raise your head so that you are looking slightly forward and unbend slightly at the hips so that your chest is no longer resting against your thighs. Keep your back flat and straight. Create a triangle between your feet, head, and hips. Alternatively, you can keep your fingertips resting on the floor for this pose. 5. Exhale and return to the forward fold. From the half-standing forward bend, slowly return to your previous position. Slide your hands back down your shins so that you are grasping your ankles. Make sure to keep your back straight as you bend forward and rest your chest against your thighs. 6. Get into a plank pose. Inhale and place your hands flat on the floor. Carefully step back with both feet, one foot at a time, extending your legs straight out behind you with your toes curled under you. Keep your arms straight and your shoulders directly above your wrists, and keep your back straight and flat. Your hands should be shoulder-width apart, and your feet should be hip-distance apart. 7. Lower yourself into a low pushup. This is also known as the 4-limbed staff pose or Chaturanga Dandasana. Exhale and bend your arms at the elbows so that your torso is parallel to the floor. Push back through your legs into your heels, keeping your legs straight out behind you. If you’re not strong enough to do a low pushup, lower yourself down so that your knees, chin, and chest are on the floor. 8. Inhale and enter an upward dog pose (Urdhva Mukha Svanasana). Push your toes out behind you so that the tops of your feet are resting flat on the floor. Keeping your arms straight and your hands resting flat on the floor, raise your head and push your chest forward and your shoulders back so that you enter a backbend. Allow your shins to rest on the floor, but try to keep your thighs and hips slightly elevated. 9. Get into a downward dog pose (Adho Mukha Svanasana). Exhale and roll your feet back onto your toes, keeping your legs straight out behind you. Let your head hang down and move your hips up and back, pushing through your shoulder blades. Keep your hands flat on the floor and your arms straight. Keep your back and legs straight and aim your hips directly at the ceiling. 10. Move back into the standing forward bend. From the downward dog position, inhale and step forward with one foot, then the other. Move your feet so that they are in line with your hands and closer to the front of the mat. Keep your legs and back straight, and bend at the hips. 11. Inhale and move back into the upward salute. Slowly straighten up until you are standing upright, then raise your arms above your head, turning your gaze upward. Keep your hands facing each other or touching, palm to palm. Push your hips forward and your shoulders back so that you enter a slight backbend. Keep your knees very slightly bent during this pose. 12. Exhale and return to the mountain pose. Slowly lower your arms and straighten your back. Let your hands hang at your sides in the forward-facing receptive position, or hold them in front of your chest in the prayer position. Make sure your weight is evenly distributed between both your feet. This will return you to the original pose and bring the Surya Namaskar sequence full circle.

GPT_text:
Text Steps (12-pose classic Hatha sequence)
    1.	Pranamasana — Prayer Pose (Exhale)
  Feet together, palms at heart. Lengthen the spine and settle your breath.
    2.	Hasta Uttanasana — Raised Arms (Inhale)
  Sweep arms up. Lift the chest; keep ribs knitted and glutes lightly engaged to avoid lower-back crunching.
    3.	Uttanasana — Standing Forward Fold (Exhale)
  Hinge from hips, hands to floor/shins. Relax neck; bend knees as needed to keep spine long.
    4.	Ashwa Sanchalanasana — Low Lunge, Right Leg Back (Inhale)
  Step right foot back, left knee over ankle, chest open. Option: drop back knee for comfort.
    5.	Dandasana — Plank (Exhale)
  Step left foot back. Wrists under shoulders, body in one line. Core and legs active.
    6.	Ashtanga Namaskara — Eight-Limbed Pose (Exhale to Lower)
  Knees, chest, and chin to floor (hips slightly lifted). Elbows hug in.
  Beginner swap: Lower to knees–chest–chin slowly.
    7.	Bhujangasana — Cobra (Inhale)
  Slide forward, press tops of feet down, lift chest with little hand pressure. Shoulders away from ears.
    8.	Adho Mukha Svanasana — Downward-Facing Dog (Exhale)
  Hips up and back, lengthen spine. Pedal heels; keep knees soft if hamstrings are tight. Breathe steadily.
    9.	Ashwa Sanchalanasana — Low Lunge, Left Leg Forward (Inhale)
  Step left foot between hands, lengthen through crown. Option: drop back knee.
    10.	Uttanasana — Standing Forward Fold (Exhale)
  Step right foot forward, fold. Spine long; weight balanced over mid-foot.
    11.	Hasta Uttanasana — Raised Arms (Inhale)
  Press through feet, sweep up in one piece. Lift from mid-back, not the lower back.
    12.	Pranamasana — Prayer Pose (Exhale)
  Hands to heart, stand tall and steady. That’s ½ round. Repeat, switching the first lunge leg to complete 1 full round.
  
  How to Practice
    •	Reps: 2–6 full rounds for beginners; 6–12 for a stronger practice.
    •	Pace: One breath per movement; hold Down Dog for 3–5 breaths if you like.
    •	Alignment checks:
    •	Knees track over second toes in lunges.
    •	Keep neck long in folds; hinge from hips.
    •	In Plank/Chaturanga variations, elbows skim ribs.
    •	Modifications:
    •	Use blocks under hands in folds/lunges.
    •	Drop knees in Plank and during Eight-Limbed Pose.
    •	Step instead of jump between poses.
    •	Cautions: If you have wrist, shoulder, back, or blood-pressure concerns, ease the range, use props, or skip weight-bearing steps.
  
  Want a version with vinyasa flow (Surya Namaskar A/B) or a chair-friendly set? I can make those visuals too.

Gemini_text:
The Surya Namaskar, or Sun Salutation, is a sequence of 12 powerful yoga asanas. Here are 4 visual steps for you:

1.  **Pranamasana (Prayer Pose):** Stand at the edge of your mat, feet together, and balance your weight equally on both feet. Expand your chest and relax your shoulders. As you inhale, lift both arms up from the sides, and as you exhale, bring your palms together in a prayer position in front of your chest.

2.  **Hasta Uttanasana (Raised Arms Pose):** Breathing in, lift the arms up and back, keeping the biceps close to the ears. The idea is to stretch the whole body from the heels to the tips of the fingers.

3. **Hasta Padasana (Hand to Foot Pose):** Breathing out, bend forward from the waist, keeping the spine erect. As you exhale completely, bring your hands down to the floor beside your feet.

4. **Ashwa Sanchalanasana (Equestrian Pose):** Breathing in, push your right leg back as far as possible. Bring the right knee to the floor and look up.

prompt: How to Do Yoga Walking? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Align your inhales and exhales with each step you take. Be mindful of your breath while walking, like you would be during a regular yoga session. Wear comfortable clothing and footwear to go yoga walking. 2. Do some yoga poses at various intervals along your walk. Part of yoga walking often involves pausing at times to perform a yoga pose (or a few). Start by adding 1 or 2 poses to your walk. As you get more experience, work your way up to a higher number, like 5-7. Incorporating yoga poses into your walk can help with your flexibility and relax your mind. Shoulder and spine rotations: Rotate your shoulders and your spine. Do this to remove any tension in your shoulders and your neck. Gently turn your spine to the right and then to the left several times. Turn your head along with your body. Side body stretch: Extend your arms above your head and touch your palms together. As you walk, reach over to one side, then the other. Standing spinal twist: Standing with your feet hip-width apart, extend your arms parallel to the floor while twisting your torso to one side at waist level. Repeat on the other side. High crescent lunge: While standing with both feet firmly on the ground, lunge one leg forward and extend the other back. While in the low lunge, lift your torso upright, bring your arms overhead, and focus on engaging your core and back leg. Eagle pose using arms: Lift your elbows to shoulder height while touching your palms together. Shift your elbows so one wraps around the other (the corresponding palm is higher as well). Hold for a few seconds and switch your arms to the other side. Standing forward bend: While standing still, hinge forward at the hips to fold your torso. Allow your arms to hang down (or touch the ground if you’re flexible enough). Wide-legged forward fold: Standing with your legs wider than hip-width apart, place your hands on your hips, and fold forward while extending your spine. Your hands can rest on your shins or the ground. 3. Focus on grounding yourself as you walk. Do this by consciously feeling the earth beneath your feet. Think the word "earth" while focusing your attention on the soles of your feet. Walters notes that walking yoga “is a very slow, intentional, mindful, meditative walk. Stay aware of how your feet land, along with the vibration of your foot, how it carries throughout the body, to connect to the earth and the breath. You're just letting the body move naturally.” [3] X Expert Source Sandy Walters Yoga Teacher Expert Interview 4. Practice mindfulness and visualization as you walk. Allow yourself to feel negative emotions like anger or sadness, and then do your best to let them go. Focus on a healing color, meditate on a set of numbers, or send out positive vibes to those you care about. Allow these visualizations and yoga meditative practices to help you clear your mind completely. Here are some more specific examples: Release anger by stomping on the ground while you walk. Feel any sadness you’re experiencing and cope with it by walking it off with each step. Perform a mantra while concentrating on a healing color or light; allow it to move down through your body. To relieve tension, imagine the numbers 1 to 20 in your head, chest, abdomen, legs, and feet; energetically send them into the ground (beneath the feet). Send someone positive thoughts that feel as if they’re bathed in light. For 5 minutes during your walk, consciously move all the stress out of you, until your mind becomes calm. 5. Walk freely. Go whichever way you want to. Enjoy your time out in nature, with the knowledge that you’re doing something good for your body, mind, and spirit. Keep your thoughts focused on the positive. According to anxiety and stress management coach Alexandra Janelli, walking in a natural, peaceful environment “gets you into a different headspace.” [4] X Expert Source Alexandra Janelli Anxiety and Stress Management Coach Expert Interview You’re better able to focus within, instead of being overly alert to outside stressors in your daily life.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** to practice Yoga Walking. (The visuals are above.)

# Yoga Walking — Text Steps

1. Set your intention (30 seconds)
   Pick a calm, easy pace (about 2–3 out of 10 effort). Decide your focus: “smooth breath,” “soft steps,” or “steady gaze.”

2. Align posture (Mountain-on-the-move)
   Stand tall first: crown lifted, chin level, shoulders relaxed, ribs easy, pelvis neutral, core lightly engaged.

3. Ground with breath (3 cycles)
   Breathe slowly through the nose. Feel both feet spread into the ground. Let the exhale be a touch longer than the inhale.

4. Begin walking slowly
   Roll heel-to-toe with soft knees. Keep strides short and quiet. Imagine you’re “placing” the foot rather than stomping.

5. Sync breath to steps (choose one cadence)

* **4-2-4-2**: Inhale for 4 steps → hold 2 → exhale for 4 → hold 2.
* **3-3** (gentle): Inhale 3 steps → exhale 3 steps.
* **4-6** (settling): Inhale 4 → exhale 6.
  Stay nasal. Optionally use a soft **ujjayi** whisper (slight throat narrowing) if it feels easy.

6. Arm flow
   Let arms swing naturally beside you. Keep shoulders down and wide; hands unclenched.

7. Drishti (steady gaze)
   Rest your eyes on the path about 10–15 feet (3–5 m) ahead. Keep peripheral vision soft.

8. Body scan in motion
   On each loop or minute, check: jaw soft, tongue relaxed, neck long, ribs easy, belly supple, steps quiet.

9. Add a simple mantra (optional)
   Pair words with steps or breath, e.g., **“In… calm / Out… release”** or **“Here… now.”**

10. Cooldown and close (1–2 minutes)
    Gradually slow your pace. Let the breath return to natural. Pause standing in Mountain: feel both feet, one full nasal breath in and out.

**Duration:** Start with 5–10 minutes; build to 20+.
**Where:** Quiet sidewalk, track, or park path.
**Safety:** If you feel dizzy, short of breath, or uncomfortable, return to normal breathing and pace—or stop and rest.

If you’d like, I can tailor a 2-week progression plan (beginner → intermediate) or adjust the breath cadence for hills or different fitness levels.

Gemini_text:
Yoga walking combines the mindfulness and controlled breathing of yoga with the physical activity of walking. Here's how to do it:

**Step 1: Warm-up and Intention Setting**
Before you begin, take a few minutes to stretch lightly. As you walk, bring your awareness to your breath and set an intention for your walk. This could be anything from enjoying nature to releasing stress.

**Step 2: Mindful Breathing**
Coordinate your breath with your steps. For example, inhale for 3-4 steps and exhale for 3-4 steps. Focus on deep, steady breaths, breathing in through your nose and out through your mouth or nose.
Image: A serene woman with dark hair stands on a forest path, eyes closed, hands pressed together in a prayer-like gesture. Sunlight streams through the trees in the background. The text "Step 2: Mindful Breathing" and "Coordinate your breath with your steps. Inhale for 3-4 steps, exhale for 3-4 steps." are overlaid on the image.

**Step 3: Body Scan**
As you walk, regularly scan your body for tension. Start from your head and move down to your toes. If you find tension, consciously relax that area. Notice how your feet connect with the ground, the swing of your arms, and the alignment of your spine.

**Step 4: Walking Meditations (Optional)**
You can incorporate short walking meditations. For example, focus on the sensation of your feet touching and lifting from the ground. Alternatively, you can repeat a mantra silently with each step.
Image: A barefoot woman in a green top and gray leggings walks on a forest path, head held high, eyes looking forward. Sunlight again filters through the tall trees. The text "Step 4: Walking Meditations (Optional)" and "Focus on the sensation of your feet touching and lifting from the ground. Repeat a mantra silently with each step." are overlaid on the image.

**Step 5: Cool-down and Reflection**
Towards the end of your walk, gradually reduce your pace. Find a quiet spot to stand or sit, and take a few moments to reflect on your experience. Notice any shifts in your mood or energy levels.

Enjoy your yoga walking practice!

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** for Bridge Pose (Setu Bandhasana). The visuals are provided separately above.

1. Set up

* Lie on your back. Bend knees, feet hip-width and parallel, heels under (or slightly in front of) knees.
* Arms alongside your body, palms down. Lengthen the back of your neck; gaze straight up.

2. Engage + prepare

* Root evenly through all four corners of each foot.
* Lightly hug thighs toward the midline (imagine holding a block between knees).
* On a steady inhale, lengthen your tailbone toward your knees to avoid crunching the low back.

3. Lift

* Press feet and upper arms down, then lift hips until thighs are roughly parallel to the floor and shins vertical.
* Keep knees tracking over ankles (don’t let them splay). Keep neck neutral—don’t turn your head.

4. Deepen (optional)

* Roll shoulders slightly underneath you and interlace fingers, or keep palms pressing into the mat.
* Broaden collarbones and lift the sternum toward the chin without jamming the throat.
* Keep tailbone long and ribs gently down to maintain length in the lower back.

5. Hold

* Breathe slowly for 5–10 breaths. Keep glutes active but not clenched; most of the lift comes from legs and back body.

6. Exit

* Release the hands, if interlaced.
* On an exhale, slowly roll the spine down—upper back, mid back, then low back.
* Bring knees together or hug them in for a breath or two.

Modifications & props

* **Supported Bridge:** Place a yoga block (lowest or middle height) under the sacrum and relax your weight onto it.
* **Shoulder comfort:** Keep hands by your sides instead of interlacing.
* **Knee tracking:** Squeeze a block or folded towel between thighs to prevent knees from splaying.

Common checks

* Shins vertical, knees over ankles.
* Neck neutral; weight is on shoulders/upper arms, not the head.
* Low ribs soften toward pelvis; tailbone reaches toward knees.

Contraindications & cautions

* Avoid if you have acute neck/spine injury unless cleared by a professional.
* If pregnant or with uncontrolled high blood pressure, practice **supported bridge** and come up/down gently.
* Never turn your head while in the pose.

Want a variant next (wheel, one-leg bridge, or sequencing it into a flow)?

Gemini_text:
The bridge pose, also known as Setu Bandhasana, is a foundational yoga pose that strengthens the back, glutes, and hamstrings while opening the chest and shoulders. Here's how to do it:

1.  **Lie Down:** Begin by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Your heels should be close enough to your buttocks that you can lightly touch them with your fingertips. Keep your arms by your sides, palms facing down. 2.  **Lift Hips:** Press down through your feet and arms. On an exhale, slowly lift your hips off the mat, engaging your glutes and inner thighs. Your thighs should be parallel, and your knees directly over your ankles. 3.  **Clasp Hands (Optional):** If comfortable, you can shimmy your shoulders underneath you and clasp your hands together beneath your back. Press your clasped hands into the mat to help lift your chest further. Keep your gaze directed upwards or at your nose to maintain a neutral neck. 4.  **Hold and Release:** Hold the pose for 30 seconds to a minute, breathing deeply. To release, unclasp your hands if you had them clasped, and slowly roll your spine back down to the mat, one vertebra at a time, until your hips rest on the floor. You can hug your knees to your chest to release your lower back if desired.

prompt: How to do tree pose in yoga? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Place Feet Under Your Hips. Stand with your feet about shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent. Roll your shoulders up, back, and down. Pause to feel your strength here, making sure you have equal weight in each foot and that you’re breathing to protect your back. 2. Move One Foot to the Side and Lift Your Heel. Move your left foot out to the side a few inches, allowing your toes to point out about 45 degrees. When you’re ready, lift your left heel so that you’re balancing on one leg. Continue breathing here for as long as you’d like. 3. Bring Your Foot In. When you feel ready, bring your left foot in to meet your right so it’s like a kickstand. Your left knee remains turned out to the side. Root down into your feet, and place your hands on your hips. 4. Grow Your Tree. When you feel ready, extend your hands overhead like tree branches. Breathe here for three to 10 breaths. Reverse the movement to return to mountain pose, then repeat on the opposite side.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text-only steps** for Tree Pose (Vrksasana). The visual 4-step guide is above.

1. **Set up (Mountain Pose)**

   * Stand tall with feet hip-width (or together).
   * Distribute weight evenly; lengthen your spine; relax shoulders.
   * Engage your core and steady your breath.

2. **Place the foot (build the base)**

   * Shift weight into your **left** foot.
   * Lift the **right** foot and place the sole on the inner **ankle or calf**, or the **inner thigh**.
   * **Never press on the knee joint.** Keep hips facing forward and the standing leg straight but not locked.
   * Option: keep right toes on the floor like a “kickstand” for balance.

3. **Find balance (hands to prayer)**

   * Bring palms together at your chest (Anjali Mudra).
   * Press the lifted foot and standing leg gently into each other.
   * Grow tall through the crown; fix your gaze on a still point (drishti).

4. **Grow the tree (arms up)**

   * Inhale and reach arms overhead (or keep hands at heart if steadier).
   * Keep ribs knit, shoulders soft, pelvis neutral.
   * Hold for **3–5 slow breaths**, then lower with control.
   * **Repeat on the other side.**

Here are the steps to achieve Tree Pose (Vrksasana) in yoga, with accompanying visuals:

1.  **Mountain Pose (Tadasana):** Begin by standing tall in Mountain Pose. Distribute your weight evenly on both feet. Ground down through all four corners of your feet. Engage your leg muscles, lift your kneecaps, and lengthen your spine. Your arms can rest at your sides with palms facing forward, or you can bring your palms together at heart center.
    2.  **Shift Weight and Lift Foot:** Shift your weight onto your left foot, feeling it root firmly into the ground. As you do this, begin to lift your right foot off the floor. Keep your core engaged to help with stability.
    3.  **Place Foot (Ankle or Calf):** Place the sole of your right foot either on your left ankle (if you're just starting out or working on balance) or on your inner left calf. **Avoid placing your foot directly on your knee joint**, as this can put undue pressure on it.

prompt: How to do a squat with a Squat Rack? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Start with a low weight. The most important thing with squats is to have the correct form, so you shouldn't attempt weighted squats until you can perform body weight squats with perfect form. Start with a low weight — maybe just using the bar (which weighs 45lbs) — and slowly build yourself up to heavier weights as your squat technique and muscle strength improves. 2. Position the bar correctly. Set up the squat rack so the bar is slightly below shoulder level. Position the safety bars so they are low enough to allow you to squat down fully with the bar on your shoulders. When you're ready, duck under the bar and grip it widely with your palms facing forward. Rest the bar across your upper back (not your neck). If this feels uncomfortable for you, try using a bar pad. 3. Squat using the same technique as the body weight squat. Place your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, with your toes pointing slightly outwards. Hinge your hips and push your butt backwards until your hamstrings are parallel with the floor. Keep your chest up, your shoulders back and your eyes looking straight ahead. Remember to keep your back straight — this is especially important when you are squatting with heavy weights. Push out of the squat with your heels and don't let your knees cave in towards the center. If this happens, you may need to reduce your weight. 4. Inhale on the way down, exhale on the way back up. Breathing deeply is very important when squatting heavy weights. If you hold your breath you can become dizzy, nauseous or even blackout. Take a deep breath in as you squat down and exhale powerfully as you rise up. Maintaining this breathing pattern will give you the energy you need to keep going. If you're pushing yourself to get another few repetitions, don't be afraid to pause between repetitions to take a couple of deep breaths.

GPT_text:
Here you go—one visual guide and one text guide, separated as you asked.

# Visual steps (image)

I created a clean 9-panel infographic titled “How to Do a Squat with a Squat Rack,” showing:

1. Set J-cups & safeties → 2) Load bar & collars → 3) Unrack & walkout → 4) Stance & brace → 5) Descend → 6) Bottom position & depth → 7) Drive up → 8) Re-rack, plus a “Common mistakes” box (knees caving, heels lifting, bar drifting forward, excessive arch/round).

# Text steps (detailed)

1. Rack setup

* Set J-cups around mid-chest so the bar is ~1–2 in (2–5 cm) below shoulder height.
* Set safety pins just below your expected bottom depth (they should catch the bar if you fail without touching it during good reps).

2. Load & secure

* Load plates evenly and add collars. Clear the area behind you.

3. Bar position & grip

* Walk under the bar. Place it across the upper traps (high-bar) or slightly lower on the rear delts (low-bar)—choose one and keep it consistent.
* Hands just outside shoulder width, squeeze the bar, wrists neutral (not bent back), elbows angled down/back to lock the upper back.

4. Stance & bracing

* Step under the bar with feet under hips, stand tall to unrack.
* Take 1–2 controlled steps back.
* Set feet shoulder-width (give or take), toes turned out ~10–30°.
* Big breath into your belly and sides, brace your core 360°, ribs stacked over pelvis.

5. The descent

* Keep the bar over your mid-foot.
* Break at hips and knees together; let the knees track over your toes (not collapsing inward).
* Maintain a neutral spine and steady gaze (chin tucked, eyes forward).

6. Bottom position & depth

* Aim for hip crease at or just below the top of the knee (or the deepest pain-free, controlled range you can maintain).
* Shins roughly forward, whole foot glued to the floor, weight mid-foot to heel.

7. The ascent

* Drive the floor away, push up through mid-foot/heels.
* Keep knees tracking over toes and chest tall; think “stand up with the bar” and “drive hips and chest together.”
* Exhale through the sticking point or finish the rep, then reset your breath between reps.

8. Re-rack safely

* Step forward until both sides touch the uprights, then sit the bar straight down into the J-cups.
* Don’t let go until you’re sure it’s seated.

9. Safety & spotting tips

* Warm up with the empty bar, then small jumps.
* Shoes with firm, flat or lifting soles improve stability.
* Use a spotter for heavy sets (they should follow your torso and assist only if the bar stalls).
* If you must bail alone: drop to the safeties by sitting back/soft knees and letting the bar settle on the pins—then step forward out.

10. Common mistakes to avoid

* Knees caving in hard.
* Heels lifting or rocking to toes.
* Bar drifting forward of mid-foot.
* Over-arching or rounding the back.
* Rushing the walkout (take only 1–2 steps).

11. Simple programming starter

* 3–5 sets × 3–8 reps, leaving 1–3 reps in reserve. Rest 2–4 minutes.

Want a version tailored to front squats or low-bar specifics? I can spin up a companion visual/text set.

Gemini_text:
Here are the steps to perform a dumbbell squat:

**Step 1: Starting Position**
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward. Hold a dumbbell with both hands in front of your chest, gripping one end of the dumbbell with both hands. Keep your back straight, chest up, and shoulders back.
**Step 2: Descend**
Begin the squat by pushing your hips back and bending your knees, as if you're going to sit down in a chair. Keep your chest up and your gaze forward. Lower yourself until your thighs are parallel to the floor, or as low as you can comfortably go while maintaining good form. Ensure your knees track in line with your toes and don't collapse inward.
**Step 3: Ascend**
Push through your heels and glutes to return to the starting position. Maintain a straight back and engaged core throughout the movement. Extend your hips and knees fully at the top, but avoid locking your knees.

prompt: How to Build Quads and Glutes Fast With Bulgarian Split Squats? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Find a step, bench, or box that’s about knee height. Use a stable object to prop up your foot so you’re able to perform the movement safely. Choose a step, bench, box, chair, or any other stable object with a flat surface. Make sure the object isn’t higher than your knee level. If you’re at a gym, look for a weight bench to use. Using an object higher than your knee level won’t allow you to perform the movement properly and could potentially cause an injury. 2. Stand 1–2 feet (0.30–0.61 m) away from the object in a lunge position. Take a staggered stance in front of the object. Place 1 foot forward so it’s about 1–2 feet (0.30–0.61 m) away from the box, bench, chair, or whatever stable object you’re using. The closer your foot is to the object, the more you’ll activate your quads or thigh muscles. Move your foot a little further away to activate your glutes, a.k.a. your booty, more. 3. Place your rear foot on the step, bench, or box. Standing in a staggered lunch position, take your rear foot and prop it up on top of your object. You can place your rear foot flat or on its toes, so choose the most comfortable position for you. Whichever position you choose, make sure you feel balanced and comfortable. 4. Lower your hips down until your front thigh is almost horizontal. Bend your front knee and lower your hips down to the floor. Keep your front knee in line with your foot and don’t it move past your toes as you lower down to keep your body in alignment. Continue lowering down until the thigh of your front leg is nearly parallel to the floor.Avoid leaning forward as you lower down so you don’t get off-balanced. If it helps improve your balance, extend your arms out in front of you. Otherwise, you can keep them loose at your sides or place your hands on your hips. 5. Allow your back knee to bend as you lower down. Keep your foot propped up on the stable object and maintain your balance. Let your rear knee naturally bend as you lower yourself down until your front thigh is almost horizontal. Your back knee may make light contact with the floor. 6. Return to the starting position by pushing through your front foot. Once you lower down, drive up through the heel of your front foot. Continue pushing until you return to the position that you started in. After you work 1 leg, switch your stance and workout your other leg. Aim for 3 sets of 12-15 repetitions on each leg to get a great Bulgarian split squat workout. If you’re just starting out with the movement, you can place a small pad on the ground to protect your rear knee from impact.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** (separate from the image):

1. **Set up**
   Bench ~ knee height (about 16–18 in / 40–45 cm). Stand 2–3 feet in front. Place the *laces* of your back foot on the bench (toes pointed). Hold dumbbells at your sides or a single bell in goblet.

2. **Balance & align**
   Square your hips to the front. Stack ribs over pelvis, brace your abs. Plant the front foot like a tripod—big toe, little toe, heel—all pressing the floor.

3. **Controlled descent**
   Inhale and keep tension. Drop **straight down** (not forward) for ~2–3 seconds.
   • **Quad bias:** allow the front knee to travel forward over toes with a more upright torso.
   • **Glute bias:** take a slightly longer stance, send hips back a bit, keep front shin closer to vertical.

4. **Bottom position**
   Back knee ~1–2 in (3–5 cm) off the floor; front thigh at or just below parallel. Front heel stays down, knee tracks over 2nd–3rd toe. Pause for 1 second while keeping hips level.

5. **Drive & finish**
   Exhale as you push the floor away through midfoot and heel. Keep the front knee soft at the top (don’t slam into lockout). Reset your brace and repeat.

**Build quads & glutes fast (programming tips)**

* Frequency: **2–3×/week** per leg.
* Sets/Reps: **3–5 sets of 8–15 reps** (per leg).
* Tempo: **3–1–1** (down–pause–up) for control and time-under-tension.
* Load: choose a weight that leaves **1–2 reps in reserve** on your first set; add **+1–2 reps** or **+5–10 lb** next session if you complete all reps cleanly.
* Quad emphasis: **upright torso**, let knee travel forward, optional **1–2 in heel wedge**.
* Glute emphasis: **slight forward torso**, **longer stride**, think “hips back, drive through heel.”
* Range: use the **deepest pain-free** range; elevate front foot 1–2 in if you need more ROM.

If anything pinches in the knee or hip, shorten the range a touch, slow the tempo, and ensure the front heel stays planted.

Gemini_text:
The Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg exercise that can help you build serious strength and muscle in your quads, glutes, and even your hamstrings. Here's a breakdown of how to perform them effectively and some tips to maximize your results.

**Step 1: Set Up Your Stance**

Start by standing about two to three feet in front of a bench or elevated surface. Place the top of one foot (your non-working leg) on the bench behind you. Your front foot should be far enough forward that your knee doesn't extend past your toes when you squat down. Your working leg should be directly under your hip. **Step 2: Descend into the Squat**

Keeping your chest up and core engaged, slowly lower your body by bending your front knee. Descend until your front thigh is parallel to the floor, or slightly below. Your back knee should nearly touch the ground. Focus on driving your weight through the heel of your front foot. **Step 3: Drive Up**

Push through the heel of your front foot to return to the starting position. Squeeze your glute at the top. Control the movement and avoid using momentum. **Step 4: Repeat and Switch Sides**

Complete your desired number of repetitions on one leg, then switch to the other leg. Aim for 3-4 sets of 8-12 repetitions per leg to build muscle.

prompt: How to do walking lunges? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Start in a spot where you have a clear path in front of you. You need space to do walking lunges because you’ll be traveling across the floor. Choose a spot where you have at least 15 to 20 feet (4.6 to 6.1 m) of walking space. If you’re doing walking lunges at home, your hallway or your living room may provide enough space. You can do walking lunges indoors or outdoors, but you may have more space if you go outside or to a gym. 2. Stand up straight with your legs hip-width apart and core engaged. Keep your back straight throughout the exercise. Additionally, lift your chin so that your head is facing forward, and don’t lock your knees at any point. Focusing on your core muscles will help you give them a better workout. Make sure they stay engaged. 3. Position your hands at your hips or behind your head for stability. Your arms can help you keep your balance as you do your lunges. Choose whichever position is most comfortable for you. If you’re not sure which position to use, try them both to see which one feels more comfortable. 4. Take a wide step about 2 feet (0.61 m) forward with your right leg. Lift your right leg and move it out in front of you. Land on your heel and roll your foot down onto the floor. Make sure you’re taking wide steps, as small steps won’t give you enough space to bend your knees correctly. You don’t want your front knee sliding out in front of your toes, which can happen if you take short steps. 5. Lower your body until both knees are at a 90-degree angle. Your front leg should be in-line with your ankle, and your back leg should hover about 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) off the floor. [2] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview Don’t let your front knee go past your ankle or let your back knee touch the floor. The top of your front thigh will be parallel to the floor. 6. Push off of your back (left) foot to rise out of the lunge. Lift your leg off of the floor and bring it forward. Use your front (right) leg to help pull yourself forward while maintaining your balance. You can vary your speed as you do your walking lunges. At first, do them slowly so you can focus on your form. Later, you can speed up. 7. Bring your back (left) foot forward to step into another lunge. Now, your left leg should be the front leg. Land on your heel, then roll your foot down onto the floor. Lower your body so that your knees are at 90-degree angles. To rise out of the lunge, push off with your right (back) foot. 8. Continue lunging forward until you run out of space. Alternate legs with each step to continue moving forward. After you reach the end of your pathway, turn around and lunge back to your starting point. As an alternative, you can count your reps. You can also do laps with walking lunges to really increase your workout. For example, lunge around the block or do laps at a local track.

GPT_text:
Here are the step-by-step **text** instructions. I’ll also generate a separate visual steps image right after this.

# Walking lunges — text steps

1. Start tall

* Feet hip-width (not heel-to-toe).
* Brace your core; shoulders down/back; gaze forward. Hands on hips or by your sides.

2. Step and plant

* Step forward ~2–3 foot lengths with the right foot.
* Land heel → whole foot; keep feet on “two rails” (still hip-width).

3. Lower into the lunge

* Drop straight down until the front thigh is about parallel to the floor.
* Front knee tracks over the middle of the foot (don’t cave inward).
* Back knee bends and hovers 1–2 inches off the floor; back heel stays lifted.
* Torso stays upright; ribs stacked over hips.

4. Drive up and through

* Press through the whole front foot (especially mid-foot/heel).
* Stand up, bringing your back (left) foot forward to meet or slightly pass the right.

5. Reset your base

* Pause briefly with feet hip-width and balance steady.
* Re-brace your core.

6. Repeat on the other leg

* Step forward with the left foot and repeat, walking forward for distance or reps.

### Breathing

* Inhale as you lower; exhale as you drive up and through.

### Common form cues (quick checklist)

* “Knee tracks over mid-foot.”
* “Back knee hovers, don’t slam the floor.”
* “Tall torso, neutral spine.”
* “Feet stay hip-width—don’t walk a tightrope.”

### Avoid these mistakes

* Front knee collapsing inward.
* Tiny steps that jam the knee, or huge steps that pull you into a back arch.
* Leaning the torso far forward or over-arching the low back.
* Pushing only from the toes—use the whole foot.

### Scaling & variations

* Easier: reverse lunges; split squats (in-place); light support from a wall/rail.
* Harder: goblet walking lunges (hold a dumbbell/kettlebell), suitcase carry, overhead, or slow 3–4 sec descents.

### Programming ideas

* 2–3 sets of 8–12 steps per leg, or 10–20 meters per set.
* Rest 60–90 sec between sets. Warm up hips/ankles first.

### Safety note

* You should feel your quads/glutes working, not sharp knee pain. If pain appears, stop and regress the variation or consult a qualified professional.

Gemini_text:
Here are the steps to perform walking lunges, along with a visual aid:

**Step 1: Starting Position**
Begin by standing tall with your feet hip-width apart and your hands on your hips or at your sides. Keep your core engaged and your shoulders back and down.

**Step 2: Step Forward**
Take a large step forward with your right leg. As you step, begin to lower your hips towards the floor.

**Step 3: Lowering into the Lunge**
Continue to lower until both knees are bent at approximately a 90-degree angle. Your front knee should be directly over your ankle, and your back knee should hover just above the ground. Ensure your torso remains upright.

**Step 4: Push Off and Step Through**
Push off with your back (left) foot and bring it forward, stepping past your right foot. As you do this, simultaneously begin to lower into a lunge with your left leg leading. This creates a continuous walking motion.

**Step 5: Repeat**
Continue this walking motion, alternating legs with each lunge.

prompt: How to Do Crunches? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Lie on your back on top of an exercise mat . Find a comfortable spot to lie down on the floor where you can spread out. Keep your neck and back in line. Tighten your abs and push your lower back flat against the mat the entire time you’re performing crunches to ensure your core stays engaged. If you don’t have an exercise mat, then lay out a soft towel or do crunches on a carpeted floor so you’re more comfortable. 2. Bend your knees so your feet are flat on the floor. Position your feet so your heels are about 12 to 18 in (30 to 46 cm) from your tailbone. Bend your knees to 90 degrees and keep them about hip-width apart. Make sure the soles of your feet are flat against the ground. 3. Cross your arms in front of your chest with your hands just below your shoulders. Keep your elbows pointed down toward your feet. Lay your hands flat on your chest right in front of your shoulders. Avoid putting your hands behind your head since you could accidentally strain your neck when you perform your exercise. For more resistance during your workout, hold a 5 to 10 pounds (2.3 to 4.5 kg) plate weight over your chest. 4. Lift your shoulder blades off of the mat with a smooth, controlled motion. Tighten your abs and take a deep breath in. As you exhale, engage your muscles to raise your torso off of the mat all while keeping your lower back and feet flat on the floor. Lift yourself just enough to get your shoulder blades off of the floor. Support yourself in this position for 1–2 seconds. Avoid sitting all the way up when you perform a crunch since muscles in your back and hips will take over, and you could strain yourself. Keep your lower back, tailbone, and feet in contact with the mat at all times. If your feet lift off of the ground while you’re performing a rep, have someone hold onto your feet or position them underneath something heavy. Keep your neck relaxed instead of tucking in your chin. Try to keep an apple-sized space between your chin and your chest. Looking at the ceiling can help keep you from curling your neck too much. 5. Lower yourself back down with a slow, steady motion. Gently inhale as you slowly lower your torso down to the floor. Use a smooth, controlled motion to work your ab muscles and prevent you from injuring yourself. Take a brief pause to finish 1 rep. If you rush into the next rep, you’ll end up using the momentum of your body moving instead of your muscles to lift yourself up. Additionally, you’re more likely to injure your back Try doing a set of 10–12 crunches to start working out your abs . As you start building up your core strength, try doing 2–3 sets or increasing the number of reps you do.

GPT_text:
Here are the **text steps** to go with the visual:

# Side Crunch (Side-Lying Oblique Crunch) — Text Steps

1. Set up

* Lie on your **right side** on a mat.
* Bend knees about **90°** and stack hips, knees, and ankles.
* Right forearm on the floor for balance; **left hand** lightly behind your head (don’t pull your neck).
* Keep ribs “down” and neck neutral.

2. Brace

* Take a breath in.
* Gently **brace your core** as if preparing for a light poke, keeping hips stacked and elbow open.

3. Crunch up

* **Exhale** and bring your **left ribcage toward your left hip**.
* Lift both shoulders a few inches; keep elbow wide and gaze forward.
* Knees and legs stay quiet—movement comes from your **obliques**, not from tugging the head.

4. Pause

* Hold the top position for **1 second**, keep breathing softly, feel the side squeeze.

5. Lower with control

* **Inhale** and lower your shoulders back to the start without collapsing. Maintain tension.

6. Repeat & switch sides

* Do **8–15 controlled reps**, then **flip to your left side** to work the right obliques.
* Aim for **2–3 sets per side**.

### Form tips & common mistakes

* Keep hips stacked; don’t roll backward.
* Don’t yank on your head—your hand just supports.
* Small range is fine; prioritize **slow, controlled** reps.
* If you feel your neck more than your side, reduce range and press your tongue lightly to the roof of your mouth to help stabilize.

### Make it easier

* Place top hand across your chest instead of behind your head.
* Keep bottom arm straight and use it lightly on the floor for balance.

### Make it harder

* Straighten your legs and keep feet slightly off the floor.
* Add a light dumbbell or small plate held against the side of your ribcage (still no neck pulling).

If you want variations (e.g., **side plank crunch** or **standing side crunch**), say the word and I’ll add those too.

prompt: How to do skull crushers with barbell? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Lie down on a bench or stability ball. Lie down on your back [1] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview . Your feet should be flat on the floor and your legs should be bent at the knees. If you're on a bench, your head should be at one end of the bench so you have space to use your weights. On a stability ball, just balance in the middle of your back. 2. Hold weights straight out in front of you. Start with basic weights, such as dumbbells. If you haven't done this exercise before, start small, such as with 5-lb (2.3 kg) weights. Hold the weights straight out from your chest. Your wrists should face inwards. 3. Lower the weights towards the floor by bending your elbows. Slowly bend your elbows, lowering the weights down towards your face. Keep your upper arms perpendicular to the floor, while your forearms move. [3] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview It can be hard at first, so just do your best. Some people start in this position instead of with their arms straight. How you begin is up to you. 4. Move back to the starting position. Slowly bring your arms back up to a straightened position. Repeat the movement for a total of 12 reps. You can do another set or move on to another exercise. You can also work up to more sets over time.

GPT_text:
# Text Steps — Skull Crushers (Barbell)

1. **Setup**
   Lie on a flat bench with feet planted. Retract your shoulder blades and keep a slight arch. Grip the bar (EZ-bar preferred) just inside shoulder-width, palms up. Press it to arms straight above your shoulders, wrists neutral.

2. **Lower**
   Inhale. Keep upper arms still and elbows tucked ~20–30°. Bend only at the elbows to lower the bar toward your forehead or just behind your hairline on a 2–3-second count.

3. **Press**
   Exhale as you extend the elbows to drive the bar back to the start. Don’t let elbows flare; keep wrists straight. Stop just shy of a hard lockout.

4. **Finish & Repeat**
   Re-brace your core and keep shoulder blades pinned to the bench. Repeat for controlled reps (e.g., 8–12). Rack the bar carefully when done.

**Quick cues:** elbows in, wrists neutral, bar travels slightly back toward hairline, move only at elbows.
**Safety:** start light, use collars, and consider a spotter. If elbows feel strained, lower the bar behind the head instead of to the forehead.

prompt: How to Do Tricep Dips? Show visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Sit on the edge of a sturdy chair or bench. [1] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview Bring your arms down along your sides and rest your palms on your chair, wrapping your fingers under the front of the seat. Straighten your legs out in front of you and place your heels firmly on the ground. Your seat should be stable enough that it doesn’t topple forward while you work. A workout bench is ideal if you have access to one. If you don't have a chair or bench, the edge of your bed will work too. [3] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview 2. Scoot your buttocks off the chair, supporting yourself with your hands. Driving your weight into the palms of your hands and the soles of your feet, move your bottom forward until it’s completely off the chair. Keep your elbows tucked behind you, your shoulder blades back and down, and your forearms perpendicular to the floor. Position your hands so that your fingers are facing forward rather than out to the side. 3. Lower yourself by bending your elbows back until they reach a 90-degree angle. Engage your triceps as you dip down so that your lowering motion is slow and controlled. Keep your elbows tucked straight back behind you instead of letting them flare out to get the best control for this exercise. Don’t let your bottom touch the floor. If you can’t get down to a 90-degree angle to start, that’s perfectly normal. It’s better to not dip all the way to 90-degrees than to dip too far too fast. 4. Straighten your elbows fully to lift yourself back up. Pause for 1-2 seconds at the bottom of your dip to make sure your motions are in-control. Then, engage your triceps to press your body back up, bringing your arms straight. Straighten your arm completely at the top of the move. 5. Repeat 5-7 times. If you are a beginner, start by building your strength rather than going all-out with tricep dips. Start your routine with 5-7 dips per set. Once you feel like you can safely and comfortably complete that, gradually increase the number of dips you do by 1 or 2 at a time.

GPT_text:
# Text Steps — Skull Crushers (Barbell)

1. **Setup**
   Lie on a flat bench with feet planted. Retract your shoulder blades and keep a slight arch. Grip the bar (EZ-bar preferred) just inside shoulder-width, palms up. Press it to arms straight above your shoulders, wrists neutral.

2. **Lower**
   Inhale. Keep upper arms still and elbows tucked ~20–30°. Bend only at the elbows to lower the bar toward your forehead or just behind your hairline on a 2–3-second count.

3. **Press**
   Exhale as you extend the elbows to drive the bar back to the start. Don’t let elbows flare; keep wrists straight. Stop just shy of a hard lockout.

4. **Finish & Repeat**
   Re-brace your core and keep shoulder blades pinned to the bench. Repeat for controlled reps (e.g., 8–12). Rack the bar carefully when done.

**Quick cues:** elbows in, wrists neutral, bar travels slightly back toward hairline, move only at elbows.
**Safety:** start light, use collars, and consider a spotter. If elbows feel strained, lower the bar behind the head instead of to the forehead.

Gemini_text:
Tricep dips are an excellent bodyweight exercise for strengthening your triceps, shoulders, and chest. Here's how to do them:

**Step 1: Set Up Your Station**
Find a stable surface that can support your weight, such as parallel bars, a sturdy chair, a bench, or the edge of a sturdy table. Ensure it won't slip or tip over.

**Step 2: Position Your Body**
Sit on the edge of your chosen surface and place your hands shoulder-width apart next to your hips, fingers pointing forward or slightly out. Extend your legs in front of you, either bent at the knees (easier) or straight (harder).

**Step 3: Lift Off**
Push up through your hands to lift your glutes off the surface. Your arms should be almost fully extended, with a slight bend in your elbows to avoid locking them out.

**Step 4: Lower Your Body**
Slowly bend your elbows, lowering your body straight down towards the floor. Keep your back close to the bench. Go down until your elbows are at about a 90-degree angle, or until you feel a good stretch in your chest and triceps. Ensure your shoulders don't shrug up towards your ears.

**Step 5: Push Up**
Push through your hands and extend your elbows to lift your body back up to the starting position. Focus on squeezing your triceps at the top of the movement.

prompt: How to do cable crossovers for chest? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
text_ref: 1. Ensure cables are adjusted at chest height. Stand with your back toward the cable machine. Grab the handles and hold them out to the side of your body with your palms facing forward. Draw in and brace your abs. Lock shoulder blades back and down. 2. Drive the hands forward and together in an arcing motion allowing the hands to pass with one hand above and one below. 3. Reverse the pattern and return to the starting position moving through a maximum range of motion that technique can be maintained. 4. Repeat, alternating the top/bottom hand. Maintain posture throughout. Avoid arching or slouching the back, jutting the chin forward, slouching or shrugging the shoulders.

GPT_text:
# Cable Crossovers — Text Steps

## Setup

1. Pick a dual-adjustable cable machine. Attach single D-handles on both sides.
2. Choose cable height based on focus:

   * **Midline (classic):** pulleys around chest/shoulder height.
   * **High-to-Low:** pulleys set high to bias lower chest.
   * **Low-to-High:** pulleys set low to bias upper chest.
3. Select a light-to-moderate weight that you can control for 10–15 reps.

## Body Position

4. Stand in the middle, grab each handle, and **step forward** to create tension.
5. **Stagger your stance** (one foot slightly forward), knees soft, torso tall.
6. **Shoulders down and back**, ribs gently up; brace your core.
7. Start with arms open in a wide “T”, **elbows slightly bent** (keep that bend the whole time).

## Movement (One Rep)

8. **Exhale and sweep** the hands on a smooth **arc** toward each other—like hugging a big tree.
9. Bring the handles together **in front of your lower chest** (for midline). Wrists neutral; don’t let elbows lock.
10. **Squeeze the chest** for 1–2 seconds.
11. **Inhale and return** along the same arc until you feel a stretch across the chest; stop before shoulders roll forward.
12. Repeat for target reps.

## Breathing & Tempo

* **Exhale** on the sweep in; **inhale** on the return.
* Use a **2–1–3** tempo: ~2s in, 1s squeeze, ~3s return.

## Sets & Reps (General)

* Hypertrophy: **3–4 sets × 10–15 reps**
* Finisher/pump: **2–3 sets × 15–20 reps** (lighter)
* Rest: **45–75 seconds** between sets.

## Variations

* **High-to-Low:** Start high, finish around navel/hip line (slight forward torso).
* **Low-to-High:** Start low, finish around upper-chest/face line (upright torso).
* **Single-Arm:** Great for focus and ironing out imbalances.

## Form Cues

* “Chest up, shoulders down.”
* “Arms are levers; **move from the shoulder**, not the elbows.”
* “Draw **arcs**, don’t press straight out.”
* “Stop just before the weights stack touches.”

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

* Shrugging or letting shoulders roll forward.
* Locking or pumping the elbows.
* Leaning too far or bouncing.
* Letting the handles slam together or the stack crash.

## Safety

* If you feel shoulder pain (sharp or pinchy), reduce range, lower the weight, or switch to a neutral grip.
* Warm up with light flyes or band pull-aparts first.
* This is general fitness guidance—consult a pro if you have injuries or concerns.

---

**Visual steps:** See the generated infographic above. If you’d like, I can also output separate images for each step (setup, stance, start, movement, squeeze, return) or tailor the visuals to your cable height preference.
